—If Senator Hill and the opposition continue to found their conduct of public affairs in this country on the basis of press speculation, then it is not a very solid basis on which to proceed anywhere—as they themselves have been telling us with some vigour and enthusiasm over the last few days in the context of press speculation that there would be an imminent challenge from Mr Howard against Dr Hewson, and press speculation about a major challenge looming to Mr Ray Groom in Tasmania. Both of those particular instances were clear examples—the opposition is at pains to tell us—of total fabrications, total beat ups; the press running around trying to generate stories.

PARA.TAB: Mr Morris in South Australia told us the other day that stories about the Liberal leadership were all pure press speculation—the skunks locked in a room smelling each other's whiffs, I think was the expression that was utilised. The opposition was telling us that that was pure speculation; there was no substance in that. What is the opposition's position on speculation that comes from the press? It cannot have it both ways. If the opposition conducts its approach to the affairs of this nation on the basis of chasing down every rumour and innuendo that it thinks it can discern somewhere, it will not just be Fremantle that it will be losing, it will not just be Bonython that it will be losing; it will be every by-election that might arise from here into the hereafter until the turn of the century and every general election as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and refers to the continuing and real concerns regarding the nuclear capacity of the DPRK. I ask: following the adoption by the International Atomic Energy Agency of the resolution referring the DPRK nuclear matter to the UN Security Council, are economic sanctions against North Korea now likely? What is the Australian perspective? What is an appropriate response?

—I am glad that at least someone is interested in high matters of state in this parliament. It was a very statesman-like question on a very important subject. I am glad that at least one person in this place is approaching this in the proper spirit and with the proper appreciation of what this parliament is supposed to be about.

PARA.TAB: In answer to the question that I was asked about North Korean nuclear capability and the current situation that exists there, the situation is this: the Board of Governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the IAEA, met yesterday, 21 March, under Australian chairmanship and adopted a resolution on the DPRK nuclear issue. The resolution, which we co-sponsored, expresses grave concern at North Korea's failure to allow the IAEA to conduct essential safeguard activities at its most sensitive declared nuclear sites and calls upon the DPRK immediately to cooperate with the IAEA to implement its safeguard obligations under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. The resolution also importantly asks the IAEA director-general to report to the UN Security Council on North Korea's non-compliance, which the board has an obligation to do under the terms of its statute.

The resolution is a measure of the seriousness with which the international community regards this issue. It reflects our determination to ensure that the DPRK abides by its commitments under the NPT not to develop nuclear weapons and to allow full international verification of its nuclear activities.

Referring the issue to the UN Security Council does not necessarily mean an immediate move to impose economic or any other sanctions on North Korea. The fact that the security council will again simply consider this issue should itself be a further significant signal to the DPRK. Certainly, unless the DPRK takes a more cooperative approach and fulfils its undertakings, we are likely to see measured and gradual moves in the council towards punitive action, while every attempt is made at the same time to seek a resolution through dialogue and negotiation.

As I have said on a number of other occasions, it is our hope here in Australia that a long-term solution to this problem can still be found through negotiation. We sent a message to North Korea ourselves last Friday urging it to allow IAEA inspections to be completed as a means of restarting the dialogue process. Regrettably, the DPRK has not so far seen its interests as apparently being best served by proceeding in this fashion. But we hope that, with the pressure that is being mounted and the attitude of the international community being made clear, North Korea will—as it has on previous occasions—consider its position. The government will be following developments closely and, of course, we will support any action that is considered necessary by the security council.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Mr Keating continues to hedge on the proposal for another jobs tax. As late as last Thursday he was again saying that he was `not ruling it out'. As the government promised at the last election not to introduce any new taxes, can and will the minister now rule out the question of another jobs tax?

—We have already had our semantic discussion on this particular subject on at least half a dozen previous occasions. The nature of the promise that was made at the last election was in terms of not doing anything that would add to the total taxation burden. In any event, it is not the case that a jobs levy would be regarded as a tax increase but rather as a levy which is traditionally, technically, regarded as quite different, and traditionally regarded by the Senate as something quite different from taxation because of its implications for the way the legislation proceeds. Beyond that, I have nothing further to add. I have addressed this question and given the opposition an answer in those terms on half a dozen previous occasions and I have nothing whatsoever to add, as Senator Knowles should expect.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The government has already increased the level of tax burden since the last election, which the minister again admitted the government would not do. I again ask the minister whether the government will introduce another jobs tax—and the minister should not try to say it is not a tax but a levy. What is the difference between a tax and a levy? Will or will not the government further increase the tax burden which it said it would not increase?

—I repeat: we have not made a decision about increasing anything, changing anything, introducing anything or doing anything other than considering the issue in the proper way that any government should in the national interest. The nature of our broad commitments to the tax system and the level of taxation in this country has been made absolutely clear; we have debated it on a dozen occasions. The simple matter remains that the issue has not been ruled out but nor has it been ruled in, and the opposition will not know either way until it either gets into government—which is highly unlikely in the near future—or it waits until the announcement is made on budget night.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The future wellbeing of rural-based industries will depend on their ability to improve their international and domestic competitiveness. Can the minister advise the Senate of what action the government intends to take to assist the agribusiness sector to become more competitive?

—I can. The government is committed to assisting rural-based industries to improve both their domestic and their international competitiveness. I am therefore pleased to advise the Senate that a further six projects totalling $450,000 have been approved under the agribusiness program. These grants, of course, are only part of the $23 million that is available for agribusiness programs until the end of the 1996-97 financial year, which is a long-term government commitment to ensuring that Australian agribusiness is internationally competitive.

PARA.TAB: The latest successful applications all have a focus on developing marketing and management skills that assist in the promotion of Australian exports. The six programs that are to receive funding include the New England Wool Marketing and Promotion Cooperative Ltd which has developed a unique proposal for an innovative marketing strategy for New England wool, and Ausgro Cooperative Ltd which will provide funding for a marketing skills development program to provide Ausgrow with the necessary skills for export marketing into eastern and western Europe.

There is also the Queensland quality food network. The funding here will be used in employing a consultant to assist in the coordination of the development of a network of quality food producers. The Victorian essential oils network is receiving funding to enable the development of a viable, essential oil industry in Victoria. This particular project is also assisting regional tobacco growers in Victoria—this is an important part of this grant—to transfer to a viable new industry—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Queensland tobacco growers?

—They are being looked after too. The Institute of Administration, which is part of the University of New South Wales, will receive funding to run an additional series of the well-subscribed marketing skills program which focuses upon developing marketing skills for small and medium exporters; and the Horticultural Policy Council will be receiving funding to conduct a series of Australia-wide seminars focusing on international competitiveness for horticultural industries. All of these projects that are being funded under the agribusiness scheme reflect the growing awareness in our rural-based industries that an international export focus, combined with world best practice, is the best way to ensure success in the 1990s and beyond. It is a clear demonstration of this government's commitment to ensure the necessary attitudinal change in our rural export industries.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs confirm that Japan's first fast breeder reactor is about to go critical and that this will give Japan access to weapons grade plutonium? Linked to that, is it necessary that Japan develop breeder reactors? Can the minister confirm allegations that the US military-industrial complex is behind the push for Japan to develop nuclear weapons, and that it is this fear of Japan's emergence as a nuclear power that is encouraging North Korea to deny access to the IAEA inspectors? Finally, in view of the fact that most of Japan's uranium for its nuclear program has come from Australia, what efforts is Australia making to ensure that Japan does not become a nuclear weapons state?

—It is the case that Japan's prototype fast breeder reactor, Monju, is due to reach criticality in April this year. That is not news; I think that has been anticipated for some time. I am surprised that Senator Coulter has suddenly decided to get excited about it. Japan's nuclear energy program has for some time provided Japan with access to separated plutonium. The point about that plutonium, and any new plutonium that might be generated by this particular addition to Japan's energy capability, is that it is strictly safeguarded by the International Atomic Energy Agency in accordance with Japan's obligations as a party to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Those safeguards provide very strict controls to ensure that all nuclear material is used exclusively for peaceful non-explosive purposes and is fully accounted for. All Australian supplied uranium to Japan is also, of course, subject to the stringent conditions of Australia's bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement with Japan. As to the second group of questions asked by Senator Coulter, Japan is a party in good standing to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty under which non-nuclear weapon states, parties to the NPT, renounce any intention to acquire nuclear weapons. Japan announced last year its support for the treaty's indefinite extension beyond 1995. A particular attribute of the NPT, as the central pillar of the international nonproliferation regime, is that countries which have attained sufficient scientific and technological competence to develop nuclear weapons—certainly Japan is in that category—nonetheless forswear that option through internationally, legally binding commitments. The Australian government accepts Japan's clear and frequent statements that, as a fundamental principle, it will not possess plutonium in excess of the amount required for its nuclear fuel recycling power program.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to reports, especially in New South Wales, that the government has reduced funding to early intervention centres for children with disabilities. Is this the case?

—I understand that the New South Wales government has been giving the impression that the Commonwealth has reduced funding for this very valuable program. This is quite misleading, but, of course, nothing new for a state Liberal government to indulge in. Senator West has had a particular interest in this issue; I understand she has made representations on behalf of the Orana Early Intervention Centre in Dubbo, in which she has particular interest, and she is to be commended for that. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Mr Free, has provided me with the following information, which I am sure will correct any misunderstanding that the Liberal government of New South Wales has been giving.

PARA.TAB: In actual fact, Commonwealth funding for early intervention in New South Wales has increased. It has risen to more than $5 million. As all senators would know, constitutional responsibility for education of all children lies with the states and territories. Under the national equity program, the Commonwealth provides supplementary funding to schools to improve the educational performance and outcomes of children with disabilities, including early intervention, in the case of children not yet attending school.

For 1994 distribution arrangements will vary from state to state. In New South Wales the education minister will distribute funds based on the recommendations of a representative advisory committee. At this stage, the organisations have been advised of in-principle amounts. The Commonwealth, I emphasise, is not involved in this decision-making process. It is the New South Wales education minister who has the responsibility for deciding which applicants shall receive funding, and any complaints from the people of New South Wales about that allocation have to go to the New South Wales government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the minister that his colleague Senator Richardson has not ruled out the abolition of lump sum superannuation payments saying that:

QUESTION.PARA: It is becoming one of the critical questions that we have to answer for our future.
I ask the minister will he on behalf of his government categorically rule out abolishing or further reducing lump sum superannuation payouts or introducing death duties?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are, once again, embarking on the old, familiar rubric of pre-budget speculation. Newspaper articles that have been around in abundance, suggesting that the government is about to compel people to take out all or most of their superannuation payments in the form of income streams rather than lump sums, are merely pre-budget speculations. However, the paper makes no recommendations. It has been submitted to the Minister for Social Security for consideration in the context of the treatment of allocated pensions under the age pension assets test. The issue is currently under review by a consultant, who will report to the Department of Social Security in September this year.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not exactly address the question that I asked, which was what Senator Richardson said. In view of the fact that he has not denied it or completely ruled it out, I ask the Minister whether it is this government's intention to create a larger volume of underclass people as pensioners living in poverty by keeping these options open. I ask him to say one way or the other.
—Mr President, I have already given Senator Panizza a better and more comprehensive answer than he deserves, and I have nothing to add to that question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I note that the Kopassus special forces from Indonesia are currently training in Australia, and I ask: what sort of training will be provided to the Kopassus forces? Is the minister aware that reports suggest that the Kopassus forces have been implicated in human rights abuses in Indonesia, East Timor and Irian Jaya? Have these reports of human rights abuses been taken into consideration by the Australian government in making the decision to proceed with the training in Australia?

—I am aware that at the moment the Indonesian special forces are training in Australia. The training of any regional military personnel in Australia aims to foster a regional defence relationship. It is not designed to improve the capability of Indonesian armed forces to deal with internal security matters.

PARA.TAB: A team of 25 Australian Special Air Service soldiers began training in Indonesia this month as part of exercise Night Komodo 94. At the same time, a contingent of Indonesian special forces personnel is undergoing training in Australia in exercise Kookaburra 94. This reciprocal exercise runs from mid-March to mid-April. The Australians exercising in Indonesia are undergoing weapons practice, parachuting, navigation and communications training. The exercise allows Australian troops to train in environmental conditions not commonly found in Australia. The Indonesian troops in Australia are using special-purpose Australian training facilities in Perth to undertake aircraft counter-hijacking training. Such training has potential relevance to the protection of Australian lives and property in the event that Australian aircraft travellers are caught up in a hijack incident. There are no plans for counter-insurgency training to be provided by Australian forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder, from the minister's answer, whether our willingness to train these particular forces, despite the messages we are getting through in relation to human rights abuses, gives an implicit approval of the kinds of activities that they have been heard to have been involved with in their own country.

—Australian training of any overseas troops always involves setting what we regard as the appropriate standards for armed forces. We hope to impart those sorts of values in any contact any country has with Australia. Whether the basis of the question is substantiated is another matter. I have consistently supported anti-terrorist hijacking training in Australia for a whole range of countries in the region. It is a very specialist activity, and it is one that I think Australian citizens in the long term may be the beneficiaries of.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Can the minister confirm that, as Minister for Industrial Relations, he wrote to employers of waterside labour assuring them that waterfront reform achieved at a cost of $450 million would, among other things, end the old register of all workers in the industry receiving legal preferences for any employment vacancies within the industry? How does the minister equate that written assurance to stevedores with reports that the present Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, is to introduce legislation reactivating the register and the legal preference?
—I am not sure that it is in the minister's current area of responsibility, but I leave it to the minister to decide.

—I think that is right, Mr President. If Senator Parer wants to ask a question of the minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, he should do so. When I was Minister for Industrial Relations—
—He has caught you out.

—No, he has not caught me out. It is not my responsibility. The basic rule is that honourable senators ask ministers a question relating to their portfolio responsibility. This is not my portfolio responsibility. Senator Parer should direct his question to the minister whose portfolio responsibility it is. I might say, from the perspective of my portfolio of industry, technology and regional development, that I, along with the rest of the cabinet and all of the government, am doing what I possibly can to speed the process of micro-economic reform in Australia. That includes the waterfront, coastal shipping and the rest.

PARA.TAB: We do have a record of achievement on all of those fronts which is recognised by industry. The most heartening thing about this whole subject of micro-economic reform that I have seen for a long time was the meeting some three or four weeks ago in Hobart of the state premiers and the Prime Minister embracing the whole agenda for competition policy reform. I think that will drive the next era of micro-economic reform, and, importantly, involve the states in conducting significant reforms of their instrumentalities and their structures, which many commentators say is the missing ingredient in achieving significant non-traded goods sector reform in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question I asked was: did Senator Cook, as minister, write to the stevedores, assuring them in writing, I repeat, that among other things the old register of workers in the industry receiving legal preference would be abolished? Does this not represent yet another broken promise from a totally untrustworthy government?

—Senator Parer is asking me a question that dates back some years. I wrote a lot of letters over three years as Minister for Industrial Relations. I cannot recall at this moment without notice whether I wrote a letter in the specific terms that Senator Parer has framed his question. I would be more forthcoming and less guarded in my answer to Senator Parer had I not recently had an experience in this chamber of things being said of me by members of the other side as if they were true but which were not true. That taught me one lesson: to be cautious in accepting the word of opposition figures. On this occasion I will check to see what in fact I did, and I will reply in due course.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to the United Nations International Conference on Population and Development to be held in Cairo in September. What is the government doing to stimulate discussion and awareness among young Australians of the important issue of world population growth?

—I thank Senator Foreman for a question that not only acknowledges the importance of the conference but also acknowledges that there needs to be an emphasis on youth involvement. Of course, the underlying factor is that youth will be the most affected by the issues to be canvassed at the conference, particularly the issue of global population growth. As a government, we have decided to focus on youth involvement in the lead-up to the conference. I have decided to establish a national essay competition to encourage young Australians to think about the issues that will be canvassed at the conference.
—Are you marking the essays, Nick?

—With expert assistance from Senator Schacht, maybe. Issues such as the impact of world population growth on the quality of human life and the environment and how Australia can contribute to solving such problems as population growth will be canvassed by the conference and, I am sure, will be the focus of the essay competition. The competition will be open to all secondary school students in years 10, 11 and 12. They will be invited to write an essay of about 1,500 words on the topic `Australia and world population growth'.

PARA.TAB: As the focus of the conference will, of course, be the event—which is held only once every 10 years, this time in Cairo—the first prize in the competition will be a unique experience for the winner: a chance to attend the conference with a chaperone as an observer with the Australian delegation. The second and third prizes will be $300 and $200 respectively, the cash prizes being donated by the Australian Population Association.

The prize and the process has the cooperation of the Australian Geography Teachers Association, and that association will assist the department of immigration in running the competition. As I say, the prize winners will not be determined by Senator Schacht and me but by a panel of expert judges on the basis of their academic merit, taking into account—

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't be the chaperone either.

—No, but I will be there. They will take into account the quality of research analysis and presentation. This question focuses on an important aspect of this particular conference. It is a conference that will canvass a whole range of issues governing the relationship between population, development, the environment and related matters, and encompass issues relating to the status of women, health, population distribution, migration and use of resources by governments and other groups. This essay competition will ensure that young Australians will focus on the conference as an important event on the international agenda and also as an event which is relevant to their situations within Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. Does the minister stand by his offensive remarks made during the Estimates Committee F hearing this morning that a series of questions put to him by me were like arguing about `the tariff on gas at Auschwitz'?

—This question relates to a series of questions that were asked not only this morning but also at a preceding estimates committee hearing and, I imagine, at a series of hearings before that as well. They go to the provision of information about the cost of lawyers involved in particular cases. The government's position on this has been quite clear and quite consistent: we will provide details of the funds involved using ballpark figures but, when it comes to daily rates, we will treat them as commercial in-confidence.

PARA.TAB: I found the series of questions asked of me again today, and the time the opposition has spent on pursuing this particular matter in not just one estimates committee hearing but a number of them, to be quite obscene. I felt—just as I do now—that the government had balanced the interests of the taxpayer on the one hand by providing figures, and balanced the interests of confidentiality, privacy and commercial in-confidence on the other by not providing the figures in the detail expected by Senator Vanstone.

I was offended by those questions. I found them penny-pinching. I do not withdraw the comments I made this morning. I stand by them because the point I was making was that, consistently throughout this process, we have had an opposition that has been bent on undermining the court processes and the government's pursuing of these matters under legislation. The point I made this morning was: if the opposition had not been so intent on undermining this process, why pick on this particular set of circumstances?

We have before this place and before estimates committees time and time again questions relating to the provision of details of costs and government expenditure. There has always been an acceptance on the other side that at some particular point we have to balance commercial-in-confidence with provision of full information. That has been accepted here. There have been a number of occasions where opposition senators have been prepared to accept information in confidence. But on this particular occasion there has been no such acceptance. We have had this snide pursuance of this information not only this morning at 8 o'clock but a number of times beforehand. I find that insulting, and I made it clear that I did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Surely Senator Bolkus, when wearing his other hat as the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs, should be the first to recognise the insensitivity of raising the spectre of the Jewish Holocaust to score his cheap, crass political points. Since Senator Bolkus obviously does not realise that, and as the question sought the daily rates paid to defence counsel in the war crimes trials as a first step in assessing whether he gave both the defence and the prosecution a fair go in the conduct of those trials, will he now tell the Senate what is wrong with wanting to make a comparison between the daily rate paid to defence counsel and the daily rate paid to prosecuting counsel? Why does he insist on protecting the details of payments to counsel when hardly anyone else in the community who has access to taxpayers' funds gets that protection?

—It is quite pertinent for Senator Vanstone to recognise that the war crimes legislation does deal with legislation passed by this parliament. It passed through a committee process. Both I and Senator Hill were chairman and deputy chairman respectively of the relevant committee. This process involved pursuing those who may have been involved in war crimes related to the Holocaust. That is the connection. That is why I felt very insulted this morning by the degree of snide questioning about this. We have made it very clear that the government has provided information with respect to the costs, but daily rates have been kept in confidence because, to do otherwise, would damage the bargaining position of government when we do go out and buy legal services. That has been made very clear, as has been the fact that by adopting this process we achieve at least a 20 per cent to 30 per cent reduction in rates available to government.

PARA.TAB: The other aspect of confidentiality is one that has been recognised in the past by this place: the recognition of privacy of individuals involved. By releasing this information, the government is of the view that we undermine the government's bargaining position and the cost to the taxpayer is increased. That is an important factor.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: University of South Australia: Salisbury Campus

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Does the federal government endorse the University of South Australia's decision to close its Salisbury Campus? Because the campus serves, in a real sense, a working class community and the area has a high Aboriginal population, is the government concerned that the closure will contravene the university's charter on access and equity? What strategies are being implemented to ensure that Salisbury's mature age students, women, Aboriginal students and working class students are not further disadvantaged? Finally, how does this decision relate to the federal government's commitment to access and equity in higher education?

—I thank Senator Bell for giving me some notice that he was going to ask this question so that I could get some information for him. I have been provided with information from my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

PARA.TAB: The University of South Australia has prepared an internal discussion paper based on its capital management plan. The plan looks at the future development of each campus, including each campus having a particular academic focus. The institution is also planning to develop new facilities in the city to ease overcrowding and to consolidate the faculties, provide more dedicated research floor space and reduce reliance on leased accommodation.

It is understood that there are no further developments planned for the Salisbury Campus and that the consolidation of faculties would eventually lead to a move from the Salisbury Campus to the Levels Campus. I point out as a South Australian senator that the distance from Salisbury Campus to the Levels Campus is only a few kilometres, so it is not a great distance. It is on the major transport route in Main North Road through the northern suburbs of Adelaide. So it is not as though it is going from one side of Adelaide to the other. This rationalisation will substantially reduce operating costs. This is part of a long-term strategic planning exercise for the university, and it would be unlikely to be fully implemented before the year 2000.

The university has indicated that it does not intend to dispose of the campus site. An advisory group to the Vice-Chancellor has been set up to determine alternate uses for the campus, including the possibility of its being used for the provision of enabling courses for the northern suburbs. The advisory group, which includes community representatives, is expected to report to the Vice-Chancellor in April of this year.

In relation to the particular aspect about equity, I am further advised that all institutions are required to have an equity strategy within their educational profile. The Commonwealth would expect the University of South Australia to have regard to that strategy in any proposed redevelopment of its campus. The Commonwealth would want to be assured by the institution that these students would not be disadvantaged, and as a result DEET will seek advice from the South Australian university that the students would not be disadvantaged.

I also point out to Senator Bell from my own knowledge that the University of South Australia does have a deputy vice-chancellor for equity, Eleanor Ramsay, who deals with such issues as have been raised in Senator Bell's question. The university is therefore very sensitive, I understand, to the equity issues as they affect parts of the northern suburban communities of Adelaide that may be disadvantaged vis-a-vis the rest of the metropolitan area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. I refer to the peace clause negotiated as a key element of the final agreement on agriculture in the GATT Uruguay Round. Does the so-called peace clause prevent Australia from challenging unfair trade practices by the US or the EU, such as subsidised exports into traditional Australian markets, for the six-year duration of the round or for a period of nine years? Has the peace clause effectively exempted the common agricultural policy from international challenge until the year 2003?

—I will not commit myself to a precise explanation of what the effect of that peace clause is in the particular context of subsidy supports. Basically, it means, when applicable, no challenge is formally made under the GATT process, but on the understanding of a commitment to observing fully those undertakings. I will give Senator Boswell a full and clear answer on that specific question as soon as I have access to the relevant material, but I would not want to chance my arm on anything as sensitive as that without having checked first.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Electricity Supply Industry: International Performance Measures

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. It relates to a report published last week by the Bureau of Industry Economics on international performance indicators for the electricity supply industry. Can the minister advise the Senate of the progress Australia's electricity supply industry has made in relation to its international counterparts, and the importance of such benchmarking studies in further developing micro-economic reform?

—The economic research wing of my portfolio, the Bureau of Industry Economics, published on 16 March another benchmark study, this time in electricity generation and supply in Australia. This is part of a series of benchmark studies in which we compare the efficiency of industry sectors in Australia with the best performed industry sectors elsewhere in the world in order to identify the performance gap, if there is any, and encourage those sectors to become globally the most efficient of all.

PARA.TAB: This study was into electricity generation and supply. It found that prices for electricity in Australia affect all businesses right across the board. Some are more intensive than others, but if we can reduce the cost of electricity tariffs we make a major input saving to Australian business and hence improve its competitiveness worldwide. Roughly three to five per cent of all industry costs in Australia are incurred by the purchase of electricity.

It found as well that Australian industry on a world scale pays much less for its electricity than just about every other country—only two beat us in the OECD. They were New Zealand and Canada, both of whom generate their electricity mostly by hydro-electricity generation, which is the cheapest and most efficient way of producing electricity. I might say, inter-alia, that the Scandinavians, who do the same, have more expensive electricity than Australia, despite the fact that they have a higher percentage of hydro-electricity power generation.

It was found overall in this country that there are pockets in New South Wales and Western Australia where there are low volume customers who do pay higher prices than some of our more significant international competitors. It found that the price mix between industry and householder consumers favoured households in Australia over industry, although that gap was closing slightly in 1991-92.

The study found that on the scale of productivity of our power utilities, if benchmarked against investor-owned US power utilities, there was still a gap in favour of the United States. The most efficient generators in Australia are in Queensland and the least efficient are in Victoria. It is a worthwhile study. It is an auditor's report on the efficiency of this important industry sector. Obviously it begs the question of what is being done about it.

I acknowledge the work being done by my colleague Senator Collins in his new portfolio and in the development of the national electricity grid in the eastern and southern states of Australia. It is designed at getting an economy of scale, eliminating overlap and duplication of services, and delivering an efficient electricity supply service.

This latest report compares Australia's standing in relation to price, reliability and operating efficiency with international best practice and is an important tool for monitoring progress made in micro-economic reform. Studies of this type identify the gaps, as I have said. I expect that this report will provide a further incentive for ongoing micro-economic reform in this vital area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister responsible for customs. I refer to the statement in the Senate last Thursday, 17 March, by Senator Gareth Evans, regarding the disallowance of Mr Frank Kelly's pay determination that, and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . a legitimate government financial arrangement was made in order to move sideways someone who had not been a success . . .
And his reference to, and I quote:
the traditional flexibility that governments have had to act fairly and negotiate these sorts of arrangements with individuals . . .
Since the minister has consistently denied that a deal was done for Mr Kelly, can he please explain the difference between negotiating an arrangement and negotiating a deal?

TALK.START.PARA: —I find no difficulty with the comments made by Senator Evans and my own comments. There is no difference. I have explained to the Senate on numerous occasions, including in that disallowance debate, that there were discussions between the comptroller-general and me. As a result of those discussions Mr Kelly resigned as comptroller-general. Further discussions took place with appropriate officials in the Commonwealth Public Service, which led to Mr Kelly being offered a job commensurate with his skill. I have explained on many occasions that even the Conroy review said that customs is to be congratulated for what it has been doing on an international level, in the introduction of electronic systems, paperless systems, and international customs harmonisation, in which Mr Kelly has played a leading role. Therefore, it was quite appropriate that Mr Kelly be offered the job of consultant to DITARD for a couple of years as we develop those processes. There is nothing inconsistent in what Senator Evans and I have said on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that those opposite had a small victory last week in the disallowance. I refer Senator Ferguson to the editorial in the Canberra Times newspaper of last week, which has never been very friendly towards customs. It made the point that there seemed to be a bit of a witch hunt by the other side and that was unfair to Mr Kelly. He did not have the opportunity to defend himself in this place despite many allegations made against him. Senator Ferguson can try and try again, but he will not get an answer other than the one I have given—because that is the correct answer; it is the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister seriously expect us to accept the argument that negotiating an arrangement is different from negotiating a deal? Is it not the case that the statement by Senator Gareth Evans about negotiating an arrangement completely contradicts Senator Schacht's previous statements both in the Senate and in an estimates committee where he denied that a deal was done? If this is the case, has he misled the Senate and Estimates Committee E in his previous statements on this issue?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Australia is a leading exporter of agricultural commodities and last year earned more than $4 billion from the export of meat and livestock products. Will the minister advise the Senate of the efforts being made by the government and the industry to commercialise and fund new technologies in agricultural innovations, particularly in meat industry research and development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a very positive story to tell in this respect. The meat and livestock industry was our largest agricultural export earner in 1992-93, and the potential exists to significantly boost its earning capacity by moving into the higher value added food product sector. The impediment to achieving that potential is as Peter Roberts correctly points out in today's Australian Financial Review. He states:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . while we excel in food science we lack the mechanisms for funding the commercialisation of the resulting innovations and new technologies.

The meat industry is well aware of the potential for further value adding. The industry is encouraging the adoption of new technologies and innovations through the Meat Research Corporation. As I said before in the Senate, I think the best thing that John Kerin did, among a lot of good things, was to set up that series of research corporations and councils in 1985.

PARA.TAB: The MRC is jointly funded to around $50 million a year by the government and meat industry levy payers. The MRC approached the government in late 1991 proposing to develop a fund to invest in rural innovations. The government supported the proposal. Following consultation with the meat and livestock peak industry councils, it was decided to set up the agribusiness trust fund. The agribusiness trust account is a subsidiary of the MRC and is managed by Hambro-Grantham Ltd. It will invest in companies which commercialise the results of research and development to the benefit of the meat and livestock industry.

The trust will hold less than 50 per cent equity in each of its investments. It will operate on a strictly commercial profit objective and decisions will be based on stringent commercial and financial criteria. The MRC has set aside around $5 million for the trust fund over the next three years and this could leverage to over $15 million for commercialisation of new technologies. The actual size of the fund will depend upon the availability of investment opportunities.

The announcement of the trust coincides with the trust's first investment which is in a food processing software company, Sastek Pty Ltd, which will commercialise video imaging analysis technology that has been developed by the MRC. The investment involves the progressive acquisition of up to 25 per cent of Sastek, which is an $11 million company specialising in the design, manufacture and supply of management information systems for food processing industries. The government welcomes the establishment of the agribusiness development trust account. It is an approach that should help increase the adoption of new technologies and innovations by our extremely important beef export industry. This is yet another demonstration of the success of government working with industry to build on their competitive strength and develop a greater value added export base for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. I refer Senator Gareth Evans to the fragile state of the tobacco industry in Far North Queensland which, according to the Cairns Economic Research Unit, could see 880 jobs lost within the Mareeba district. I also refer the minister to his suggestion that it may not be possible to challenge protection arrangements under the peace clause in other countries. I ask: will the Australian government be challenging the US 75 per cent local content scheme which the US introduced last August to protect its tobacco growers? In view of this new US scheme and other highly subsidised tobacco industries elsewhere in the world, will the local 50 per cent mixing regime in Australia be maintained or will Australian tobacco growers be the only ones left out in the cold in this area?
—That is a detailed question. I do not have a brief on it. I will take it on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Are Australian companies keeping up with technological innovation in the advanced communications industry? How does the federal government assist companies like Codan Pty Ltd of Adelaide to compete on an international basis?

—As the Minister for Science and Small Business, it is good to be able to give details of a success story. As a South Australian senator, it is even better to relate a success story, particularly when the company is Codan Pty Ltd. Mr Mike Heard, the managing director of Codan, was appointed a member of the Australian Space Council by the government. I want to congratulate the company for its outstanding success in its highly competitive field of telecommunications technology.

PARA.TAB: The company has very successfully developed a commercial system for transmitting faxes and computer information from the world's most remote areas without having to rely on a telecommunications infrastructure. The system, called Codan 9001, can send data up to 4,000 kilometres through a 12-volt high frequency radio and can be linked to a standard fax machine and personal computer. I understand that the system has sparked keen interest overseas and that Codan's initial sales expectations have risen from $4 million to about $10 million.

This high-tech company, which has its head office in Adelaide and has been operating for many years, is now a world leader in high frequency radio and satellite communications technology. It employs 250 people and has an annual turnover approaching $30 million. Around 70 per cent of the company's output is exported to over 130 countries, including many in our own region as well as in Europe.

Codan has received a number of grants through the R&D program administered by my department, resulting in the successful commercialisation of various products. In fact, judging by the figures provided, grants of $1.2 million provided to Codan through the R&D board have resulted in sales in excess of $50 million. This is evidence that the R&D grants program is paying its way and is providing the sort of productive outcomes the government seeks. This ought to be acknowledged as one of the successful programs in our portfolio, and, again, I congratulate Codan for being at the world cutting edge of this new technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Federal Court decision in CTC Resources No Liability the Federal Commissioner for Taxation whereby a taxpayer cannot appeal a private ruling by the Australian Taxation Office where the transaction has not been executed before the end of the tax year to which the private ruling relates. Is this consistent with a self-assessment system? Is it not a denial of taxpayers' rights in the resolution of disputes? Does the government agree with the outcome? If not, will the government amend the law?

—I have to admit I do not have a brief on this particular decision. I am called upon to offer, on behalf of the Treasurer, an opinion about a ruling. I think it would be quite sensible and responsible of me to ask the Treasurer what his view of that ruling might be so I can better answer the question, and I propose to do that. I will put Senator Watson's question on notice and give him a reply as soon as I possibly can.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate condemns the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) for his insensitivity in using the appalling spectre of the Jewish holocaust in an effort to score cheap political points and his unwillingness to withdraw the offensive remarks he made in Estimates Committee F.

We rarely move motions in this way, but every now and again there is an event that leaves us with no alternative. The attack by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, on one of my colleagues in an effort to bring a line of questions to an end by, in effect, accusing her of asking questions such as `raising an issue like the tariff on gas at Auschwitz', and the insensitivity of that answer in relation to those who suffered and so continue to suffer as a result of the appalling events of the Jewish Holocaust, leaves us with no alternative but to move in this way.

PARA.TAB: I trust that those who believe that certain standards should be maintained in this chamber—and particularly that certain standards should be accepted and maintained by ministers in this place—will see that this chamber has no alternative but to bring this minister to account in this way today. I submit the matter cannot be allowed to rest in the way it is now. If no action is taken at all, it can only leave the public with the impression that we as a Senate, as a parliamentary chamber, believe that that sort of political tactic by a minister is an acceptable form of bringing a political debate to an end. This chamber should not allow that to occur. It should therefore take the course of action that is appropriate to it now and seek to debate the minister's appalling references and, hopefully, pass this motion in order to demonstrate to the Australian public that certain standards are necessary, even if they are not to be upheld by a minister of the Crown.

I am even reluctant to address the question of the line of debate that was taking place in the estimates committee this morning, but I will do so only to the extent of asking how a line of questions that was trying to explore whether public expenditure used in the defence case was fair and reasonable could be criticised as being equivalent to asking questions as to the tariff on gas at Auschwitz. That such a thing was said is simply beyond me. If there were a debate on the merits—and I do not want to go down the line on the merits—as to whether such a statement was ever justified, it certainly could not in any possible sequence of events be justified by the line of questions that was asked.

To take it one step further, when the minister was given the opportunity in this chamber today to withdraw and apologise to those who were offended by that statement, he refused to do so. I could not believe that that occurred today. I am not surprised that he attempted to make some political defence for the action he took this morning, but I was amazed that he was not even prepared to acknowledge that it was an inappropriate remark for a minister to make; that it was insensitive and offensive; and that any minister wanting to maintain a reasonable standard of conduct would recognise it as such, withdraw it, and apologise to those who were offended.

I trust that the Senate—particularly the minority parties—will recognise that the record should not stand as it is at the moment and require Senator Bolkus to withdraw and apologise. I trust that we will be supported in the action we are taking to best ensure that that does occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion, let me put this particular comment in context. To do that, let me read what I said this morning, which will give the true context:

SPEECH.PARA: While there are still victims alive and even when they have died of that holocaust, I think it is still the responsibility of civilised countries to pursue it in the way that we did. I just cannot see why we are singling this out. As I said, this matter comes up day after day, week after week, in terms of commercial-in-confidence.
That is the point I made. I think while there are still victims, and I know them—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you finish the quote?

—Hold on a moment. Firstly, I feel for the victims, and the children of the Holocaust. Secondly, I made the point that I resented then, as now, the way that the opposition has taken a penny-pinching approach to the pursuance of the war crimes trials. Senator Vanstone, wanting to ask about costs, comes in here today and says, `Well, I've pursued these questions because I want to ensure that people in these cases have adequate and competent representation'. The cost details were provided, but not the daily rates. I made it very clear that we could provide information on the daily rates in confidence. That information can still be provided in confidence, as is quite often done in relation to commercial-in-confidence transactions.

PARA.TAB: When this point was pursued this morning by Senator Vanstone, she made the point that she was pursuing it not to ensure that everyone had fair and adequate representation, but because she was concerned that we were `fixing up our mates'. That is the slant put on this point. Senator Vanstone said, `It is whether you do some friends a favour, for example'. That was the point that she was pursuing. I went on to say that I felt this particular line of attack was insulting. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is like arguing about the tariff of the gas at Auschwitz.

I have had a long concern about this issue, which has been expressed in my chairing of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I believe that, as a civilised nation, we had no option but to pursue these cases with the fullest resources, which is what we did.

PARA.TAB: I concede that I could have expressed my distaste in a better way than I did this morning. I could have judged it better, but I stress that I was expressing my distaste. If my comments caused offence to anybody then I truly apologise. My motivation on this matter is not to insult those victims or children of the victims, but to ensure that we, as a nation, can stand up in the international community and say quite clearly and fairly that we did everything within our capacity to track down those who might have been responsible for these horrendous crimes. That has been my consistent point of view. My motivation was that, having been frustrated by this unreasonable pursuance of this information by the other side, I felt offended. I apologise if, for some people, the comments were distasteful—I imagine that they may well have been, and I regret having used them. But, my motivation has always been to ensure that these crimes can be recognised as distasteful, both officially and unofficially, by our nation.

Repeating what I said earlier in respect of information, I point out that people in this place consistently seek it, and we provide it to the extent that we can. But there have been a number of occasions where the government has asserted that the information being sought has been commercial-in-confidence. In those circumstances there has always been a mechanism—people have decided not to pursue it keenly in order to make political points, but have been prepared to sit down with the government and accept that in some circumstances the information can be commercial-in-confidence. That mechanism was available this morning, and is now. If members of the opposition are serious about this, they should sit down with us and accept that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Hill. I was fascinated to hear Senator Bolkus's selective quotations from this morning's estimates committee. He obviously chose not to repeat the remarks that he made.

PARA.TAB: It is important for people to understand what the situation is—otherwise they cannot understand the urgency with which we want to consider this matter. Time and again the question was put—I think it was six times, but it might have been eight—to the minister asking him to provide the daily rates paid to defence counsel in the war crimes trials. The argument was put that when one knows the daily rate paid to a counsel one can get some idea, but not a complete one, of the level of competence of that counsel. Then, at the next estimates committee one can get the daily rate paid to the prosecuting counsel in this matter, and get an idea whether this legislation has been administered fairly. I do not believe that those questions are in any way inconsistent with the sentiments expressed by Senator Bolkus. If he genuinely believes what he said—which I think he does—that these people ought to be dealt with and that we should play our part internationally, he must agree that we have to play that part fairly. He must agree that the prosecution should have an equal chance with the defence, and that the defence should have an equal chance with the prosecution. One should not be inhibited in any way as opposed to the other.

The minister says he is happy to make public the total amounts paid to the separate counsel. But that is no help, because someone who is paid $5,000 a day and works for 10 days gets $50,000; but someone might get $50,000 for 20 days work and only be paid $2,500 a day. The daily rate of $2,500 versus $5,000 does not tell us that one lawyer is twice as good as another, but it does give us an indication of the level of counsel that the government sought to give each side. Surely, to conduct these trials as fairly as possible, we would want to have counsel of roughly equal competence, and I do not think that is an unfair question to pursue.

The minister says, `You can have the information about daily rates on a confidential basis'. What good is that? If I find that the daily rates are so disproportionate that I want to make the claim that each side was not dealt with fairly, how can I let Senator Chamarette know, for example, or Senator Kernot, Senator Harradine or anyone else? I just have to know privately that the wrong thing was done—if I believe that is the case. So to offer it in confidence is no help.

I make the point that the time is coming very near when legal counsel in any matter—let alone the war crimes trials—will not be entitled, when they have their hands in the Commonwealth till, to be protected from parliament or the taxpayers knowing on what basis their fees are calculated. We have the cost of justice inquiry being run by a committee of this chamber, which acknowledges that the government is an extraordinarily large user of legal services. It should be using its power to reduce those services, and one way it could do that is by having an open market in this matter and releasing the daily fees. At the last estimates we were told by Mr Rose from the department that all bars know there is this hefty discount; all bars in Australia work for the Commonwealth for hefty discounts.

I put the case that there is no commercial-in-confidence to protect. I say that to indicate the perfectly placid nature of the estimates committee until, suddenly this morning, the minister decided to interject with his quite offensive remark that the proper pursuit of these questions was tantamount to arguing over the price of gas at Auschwitz. I was simply astounded. It is the most tasteless remark I have heard from anybody since I have been in parliament. I do not think, if I stayed here another 20 years, I would hear a more tasteless remark. Senator Short was there and he was equally flabbergasted.

Senator McKiernan makes the point that no point of order was taken. The chairman might not have asked the minister to withdraw, but the minister was asked. He was given another opportunity here today to withdraw, and still sought—until wiser counsel probably advised him—to stick by those tasteless and insensitive remarks. It is the most appalling way for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and multiculturalism to behave, and he deserves to be condemned for doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as one who has solidly supported the war crimes trials—as has my party—and to put on record this nation's disgust with what has happened, and the need to prosecute those responsible. The motion moved by Senator Hill to suspend standing orders to censure the minister for the remarks he has made is, on the face of it, appropriate. However, the minister has apologised, and the Australian Democrats accept his apology that he has offered to the Senate in this chamber. In our view, there is therefore no need to waste the Senate's time for a full half hour on a motion when the minister has acknowledged that his remarks were offensive—I certainly found them offensive—and I believe that that is where the matter should rest.

PARA.TAB: The other matter raised as to the disclosure of fees paid to counsel is one that I believe needs to be pursued. However, it is not the subject of the censure motion and should be dealt with at a different time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a very short contribution. Obviously it is a serious matter if someone were to say, without any shred of justification or in a context which made it unbelievable, something of the kind which is being suggested was said on this occasion. Context is everything, however, in these situations. Unfortunately, we do not have the Hansard before us; we have only the words of the contending parties.

PARA.TAB: On the face of it the context was really pretty clear. What was happening was a series of questions being asked, apparently following an earlier course of questioning in other contexts, about the conduct of the War Crimes Tribunal. It is a highly sensitive issue about which the government has felt very strongly. It was only with the utmost reluctance that we wound up our own commitment to prosecuting war crimes in this country. It is an issue of great sensitivity and requires great sensitivity when being dealt with.

The context in which Senator Bolkus found himself was, I am told, and as he has told the Senate, one of a quite hostile course of questions being asked which were to the effect that, in the arrangements made for defence counsel and for counsel assisting in this matter, they were of a kind that amounted to `fixing up your mates' or `doing your friends a favour'. To have suggestions made of that kind, if indeed they were made, as Senator Bolkus says they were, is to create an environment in which one can readily understand someone responding emotionally and saying, `Well, you have really just missed the whole point as to what these war crimes proceedings were about'.

The nature of the horrors involved and the order of magnitude of the gravity of crimes are not such as to make it appropriate to be asking point-scoring questions about legal fees, in particular in the context of alleged favouritism to mates and friends. It is understandable, I suggest, that someone would react emotionally in that situation and respond in the way that Senator Bolkus did. He has frankly and straightforwardly acknowledged that the use of the expression in question was a misjudged one. He has explained the context in which he used the expression in question.

I think, as Senator Spindler has very graciously said, that the Senate ought to accept that particular explanation and get on with its business. Senators opposite should acknowledge that perhaps sometimes it is their own behaviour that can in fact give rise to these situations about which they complain.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was at the hearing of Estimates Committee F this morning, and for that reason I wish to say a few words in very strong support of Senator Hill's motion. I think the Hansard record will show quite unequivocally that Senator Vanstone this morning was pursuing a totally legitimate line of questioning about the expenditure of public money on legal fees and the principle of this government's use of the commercial in confidence defence in refusing to disclose details of legal fees paid by the government in pursuit of its activities.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that for some reason—I do not think any of us really understood the reason—Senator Bolkus appeared to be extremely sensitive about this issue and took great offence. This afternoon his explanation to the Senate for his extreme sensitivity seemed to me to be quite patently inadequate. Surely other things must have contributed to his view. As a result his whole approach was totally obstructive and was very provocative indeed. His statement, to which the coalition takes such great offence, really came out of the blue. To accuse a member of parliament of either house by saying that the pursuit of legitimate questions was like arguing about the tariff on gas at Auschwitz is a totally unacceptable statement, almost regardless of the provocation. It is even more unacceptable when that alleged provocation was the pursuit of a quite legitimate line of questioning.

In the estimate committee hearing, both Senator Vanstone and I asked Senator Bolkus to withdraw his remark. We drew attention to the fact that the relevant standing orders of the Senate also govern the conduct of Senate committees, including estimates committees. Senator Bolkus refused to withdraw. In the Senate this afternoon we again asked him to withdraw. Again, he refused. Senator Bolkus, by his refusal to withdraw in the Senate this afternoon, has quite clearly contravened standing order 193(3) which says that a senator shall not use offensive words against any member of either house and that all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on those members shall be considered highly disorderly.

I believe there is no reasonable conclusion that anyone could come to in this matter other than that Senator Bolkus contravened standing order 193(3) in the most offensive and obscene way that I have ever seen a member of parliament so contravene that standing order. He stands condemned for that, and that is the reason Senator Hill moved the motion in the terms that he did. It is all the more deplorable that a minister for immigration and ethnic affairs should use the terms that Senator Bolkus used. Senator Bolkus should unconditionally withdraw the remarks he made today in the estimates committee hearing. He stands condemned anyway. He will stand condemned for the rest of his parliamentary life if he does not now withdraw them.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has done so; come on.

—Senator Short said a little while ago that Senator Bolkus's actions were the most offensive and most obscene that he has seen in this parliament. PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone said the committee meeting this morning was of a placid nature. It was hardly of a placid nature because the first thing we started talking about at 8 a.m. was when we would have time to meet again to conclude the job that had been given to this particular Senate estimates committee by the Senate. It could hardly be described as a placid meeting—and that was only the start of it. We then talked about the questions put on notice at the estimates committee by the relevant senators. Of course, the first question related to the issue in front of Senator Bolkus which led to his uttering the unfortunate words—words for which he has since apologised.

Another example of double standards is that, on one occasion when there was an intervention by the chair on a point of order, the minister was asked to withdraw the words, `Shut up', which he had directed to one of the committee members. Prior to his being asked to withdraw those words—those very inflammatory, insulting words—another senator had herself actually directed those words to the minister. That will be in the Hansard of the estimates committee. In debating an issue such as this, it might be better to wait until we get the full written record of what actually happened in the Senate estimates committee meeting this morning.
Senator O'Chee interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't start, Senator O'Chee; I have something on you too, mate. The point was made that we started the hearing at 8.00 a.m. I made the point to one of my colleagues that that was actually 6.00 a.m. Western Australian time. We may be pleased that we were not being broadcast directly to Western Australia. The matters that were the subject of the questions at the estimates committee meeting this morning have been raised previously. They were certainly raised over an extended period at the last round of Estimates Committee F.

—They might not have been answered to Senator Vanstone's satisfaction, but they were answered and they were answered again this morning. Senator Vanstone may not be satisfied with the answers. PARA.TAB: The manner in which questions are asked is also important. It was implied—in actual fact it was more than implied; it was said—that the reason the questions Senator Vanstone asked were not answered to her way of wanting them to be answered was that the minister was seeking to do some friends a favour.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right. You had better correct that. Why don't you read it out. I said that unless we get the information we don't know whether you are trying to do a favour for a mate.

—I have picked up Senator Vanstone's remark—`whether you do some friends a favour, for example'. The implication is there in that short quote from the Estimates Committee F Hansard this morning. I believe that we are on another exercise of muckraking in this chamber; we were on such an exercise at the estimates committee hearing this morning.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I raise under standing orders the need for the speaker to be relevant to the issue at heart, and that is whether or not standing orders should be suspended. Unless that is done—and I know it has not been done on other matters—people like me who want to say why or why not they are voting for or against this motion will not have a chance to do so before the vote is taken.

—Senator Harradine, I regret that that is probably not likely to be the case anyway, but you have raised a very legitimate point of order. There has always been some debate in the chamber as to what constitutes relevance in respect of the suspension of standing orders and, invariably, the debate gets onto the substance for which the intention to suspend is designed. I have followed the precedent and given some latitude, but I am sure Senator McKiernan is conscious of the point that has been raised by you.

—If the Senate will allow me to steer this debate back to some relevance, let us look at standing order 209 which talks of urgent necessity. The issue that we have before us is the conduct of Senator Bolkus at an estimates committee meeting earlier today. The question of behaviour at Senate standing committees and otherwise is pertinent today and it certainly requires some urgent attention. It is a topical matter and, therefore, one which should be disposed of today, and that is the reason for the urgent necessity.

PARA.TAB: We had the legitimate line of questioning by Senator Vanstone in relation to the hourly rates of solicitors as paid by the government. In reply to that we got from Senator Bolkus the statement that her questions were `like arguing about the tariff of the gas at Auschwitz'. That sort of reply is entirely inappropriate. It is not conducive to the carrying out of proper affairs in Senate committees. I think that it is appropriate for this chamber to express its opinion firmly in relation to how senators conduct themselves in Senate standing committees and estimates committees. After all, we are there for the good government of this country and the people of Australia should be able to place their trust in us that we will carry out our affairs in a proper and appropriate fashion in accordance with standing order 193 without resorting to such—I would submit—offensive language.

Senator Vanstone's inquiry is a proper one. It deals with the hourly rates applicable to solicitors. I can tell honourable senators that if a solicitor works for the Legal Aid Commission there is a public rate of pay. There is no commercial confidentiality about that at all. I do not think it would place the government in a lesser bargaining position if this were to be made public. In fact, I think it would increase the government's position, allow some sort of competition between practitioners and give a greater deduction to the Commonwealth and, indirectly, to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, you have 60 seconds, I regret to say.

—I seek leave to continue my remarks after that time so that Senator Chamarette and Senator Kernot have a chance to make a contribution to this debate. PARA.TAB: I rarely vote against the suspension of standing orders in a matter such as this. I agree with the opposition that this is a very serious matter. I heard him a moment ago apologising for using the words that he used in the context that he used them. Now there are calls for him to withdraw. There is a scale of severity and humiliation—to withdraw is one thing; to apologise is another. To apologise, as Senator Bolkus has done, is to imply that the comment that has caused such offence, and rightly caused such offence, has indeed been withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe there are two issues here and I agree with Senator Harradine that they have not been adequately canvassed. The first is the refusal to disclose information to Estimates Committee F; the second is the very offensive implication of a remark made by the minister.

PARA.TAB: The Greens believe that estimates committees should not be treated with contempt by anybody and that they have a legitimate role to play. The disclosure of information is a recurrent problem. The government has failed many times to demonstrate true openness to scrutiny; so we certainly believe that the opposition has a point. However, the censure motion seems to be focussing on the minister's tasteless remarks. The minister has apologised for those remarks, as it was appropriate and necessary to have done so.

It is important to stress that estimates committees fall into disrepute when exchanges focus on party political point scoring or when committee members or ministers cast aspersions on each other. When, as Senator Ellison pointed out, we have set such a high standard for the way in which the Senate should conduct itself, we should bear in mind the saying that people who live in glass houses should not throw stones.

I believe that there has not been sufficient time to justify this matter being treated as a matter of urgency. It is a matter of seriousness but the Greens will not be supporting the motion for the suspension of standing orders.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PETITION.TITLE: Leaded Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the reduction of octane quality of leaded petrol from January 1994, resulting from the Government's `Lead Roundtable' meeting. The petitioners note particularly that this reduction in petrol quality:
(1) Jeopardises the use of vehicles made prior to 1986 for operation on high octane petrol and could lead to many of those vehicles suffering serious engine damage;
(2) Will result in worse vehicle operation, higher emissions and greater fuel consumption for up to three million vehicles;

(3) Will have negligible benefit to the community, through reduced lead emissions, because the oil industry proposes to leave lead levels in petrol unchanged in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, and because the use of leaded petrol already is rapidly decreasing;
(4) Will disadvantage vehicle enthusiasts and low income members of the community.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to take action to ensure the continued availability of high octane petrol for Australian motorists.
