TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend government business notice of motion No. 1 and to move the amended motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That on Tuesday, 22 March 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the hours of meeting shall be:

(b)the question for the adjournment shall be proposed at 10.30 p.m., or at the conclusion of the consideration of Government documents, whichever is the earlier, and the procedures for the adjournment shall be as specified in the sessional order of 2 February 1994 relating to the times of sitting and routine of business; and
(c)consideration of Government documents under standing order 61 shall be called on at 10.00 p.m.

I wish to briefly address that motion, and I understand that there may be some debate on it. I do not have any pleasure in moving this motion, but the need for it has arisen because of the very small amount of legislation that the Senate was able to debate last week. Honourable senators will recall that last Monday there was no time for government business. On that day there was an MPI, a first speech and a ministerial statement on Macedonia which took considerable time. On Tuesday, all available time was taken up with debating three disallowance motions. On Wednesday and Thursday there was a continuation of the disallowance debate and also considerable interest and involvement in the question of the disclosure of the pecuniary interests of senators. Consequently, at this stage, we have a backlog of legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is not a serious backlog but we do have 10 packages of bills to debate, four of which are in the committee stage, and we have three messages to receive from the House of Representatives. I estimate, and I have told Senator Hill this privately, that we need nine to 10 hours of government business time to complete the program. If we get a reasonable amount of time today, including the additional two hours tonight which are sought in this motion, we may not need further late night sittings this week.

It is always difficult—as I think all honourable senators know—to make any hard and fast predictions about what is going to occur with the Senate's business timetable. I do not intend to make those predictions, but as a precaution I would be proposing tomorrow to look at the issue of the Senate either negating or perhaps curtailing to some extent its general business debate on Thursday, if that is agreed amongst the parties in the Senate. There is the less palatable option of finishing our program on Friday. However, I believe that there will be no need for the Senate to negate tomorrow. I think we can see our program completed with a little more increase in government business time and, I hope, cooperation from all senators—opposition, minor parties and Independents.

Let me make it clear that it is not the government's intention to negate the adjournment tomorrow night but to make an assessment by the close of play tomorrow about how we are travelling with our program. If there is a need to make any adjustments for Thursday, the appropriate adjustments will be made at that time.

I do not want to second guess any contribution that Senator Hill may make in this debate. However, I predict that he may claim that this motion indicates some lack of success, or failure, in the new timetable. I do not think that that would be a fair conclusion to draw in any sense. In fact, I would strongly disagree with that. The new timetable of sittings and routine of business have meant that the Senate, throughout this particular session, has been able to rise by 8 o'clock each day and even the extra sitting hours proposed in this motion will mean that the Senate will rise at what used to be its normal finishing time. That clearly is a preferable arrangement to the previous situation when, at the end of the normal parliamentary session, there was a negation of the adjournment at 10.30 p.m. and we worked into the wee small hours of the morning. This is a responsible approach by the government—sensible, given the constraints of our legislative program—of which notice has been given for a substantial period of time. I urge all senators to support this motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will oppose this motion. It is inconsistent with the programming and timetable that were forced upon us. We voted against this not very long ago when we were told that late night sittings were unhealthy and, therefore, would not be imposed upon the Senate in the future. There was great determination on the part of the government, the Democrats and the Greens that the Senate would not sit later than 8.00 p.m. Here we are, on the first occasion when that is put to the test, and we find the government getting together with the Greens and the Democrats—the team, as we tend to refer to them these days—and deciding that they will breach their own determination.

PARA.TAB: With the numbers being as they are in this place, our view becomes somewhat irrelevant. It is sometimes forgotten that when the Greens, the Democrats and the government join together, as they so often do, we become a minority. We did protest at the time that this new system was imposed, and I think its shortcomings have now been demonstrated.

The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has made a concession—which I recognise—in that he is now prepared to undertake that he and the minority parties will not seek to impose the longer hours on the Senate tomorrow night. I respond positively to that; it is more of a concession than we had earlier today. He has acknowledged that he may well be seeking a further late night extension on Thursday, which is scheduled to be the last sitting day of this session. The point is that with proper planning this should have been unnecessary. The Senate sat a lot earlier this year than it has in the past—coming back near the beginning of February—to enable the government to better plan its program within a time frame that, according to the government, would not require night sittings. At its first test, it has failed.

The government has sought today to pass blame for that to us, which is its usual practice, but it was not our decision last week to bring upon the Senate the debate on senators' interests. It was the government's determination to get that through the Senate last week pursuant to another arrangement that it had made with the Australian Democrats and the Greens—another team effort. It was an item of business to take precedence ahead of all government legislation, notwithstanding that the government for 10 years has played around with the issue. It has brought it on occasionally and dropped it—in some instances, for up to two years—before bringing it back again. But last week it had to be the item that took precedence over all other items, including government business.

The minister said that last week the government got a bit behind in its schedule. The problem is not made any better by the fact that government members failed to attend the chamber, were counted out, and therefore lost time. One might ask the question: why does the Senate now have to suffer a night sitting—which we were told it was so important to avoid—simply because government members failed to attend during the scheduled time? It does seem incredible that when the government fails to keep its own quorum the Australian Democrats and the Greens say, `Never mind. We will join with you to extend the Senate into a night sitting' so shortly after the Democrats and the Greens told us it was critical to avoid night sittings.

I guess the good faith of the government in this matter was tested, and a lack of good faith was demonstrated, in relation to the estimates committees. Apparently sitting late at night on an estimates committee does not harm our health, but sitting late at night in this chamber does. Again, with the first test we found that the new sitting hours, in the government's eyes, did not apply to estimates committees. If those committees sat late, that was too bad, notwithstanding the health consequences. So we have had late night sittings of estimates committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —They wanted us to start at half-past six in the morning.

—The planning of this government is so incompetent that I gather at least three of the estimates committees still have not finished their work. As Senator Patterson correctly interjected, one of the government's proposals was that one of the estimates committees should meet at 6.30 a.m. There was a failure to take into account not only the health but also the sensible working practice of staff and assistants around this building.
—One is to sit between 6.50 and 8 p.m.

—That is right, but none of these concerns were taken into account. It was convenient to the government when it suggested that this committee sit at half-past six in the morning. It is now convenient to the government that the Senate should sit tonight, and, as I said, the Greens and the Democrats roll over whenever the government seems to call them in these days. That is what will occur because the government has the numbers.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we are debating this change to the timetable, I put on the record a couple of extra protests. We said at the time of the changes to the timetable that we were concerned about the changes being made to the adjournment debate. We conceded that often there is not an adjournment debate, and sometimes it is a short one, but argued that on some occasions there are issues of significance that will take longer than the maximum 40 minutes allowed. That has been demonstrated to be the case. The problem with that is if the government, the Democrats and the Greens, come in and want to participate in that 40 minutes then we, not being a majority, but certainly the largest group in this chamber, are lucky to get in one small contribution during that debate. That has been demonstrated not to work satisfactorily—certainly not from our perspective. It suits the government and the minority parties, but it is the opposition that is being restricted. For the next session, I register my protest at what is occurring in that regard.

Similarly, the government conceded during the debate on setting a new procedural structure for the Senate that the ability to take note of matters that arise during question time should become a right and not require leave. Its purpose is basically to enable opposition and minor parties to take note of matters that arise out of government answers because question time is clearly stacked against an opposition. We have just one minute to ask the question; ministers have four minutes to answer it. We argued that it should be three, but again the Democrats joined with the government to make it four. As it is televised, it is again biased against an opposition's interests.

The concession was generously made that we should have the right to take note of those matters after question time. What is happening now is that government members are coming in and participating in that process, again stacking the debate so that that right is, in effect, being lost. That is an abuse of the spirit in which that compromise was reached, and I therefore put on notice my protest.

I have already protested about the long hours that the estimates committees are sitting, the fact that there was not sufficient time scheduled within this program to allow for the proper and reasonable functioning of the estimates committees.

In summary, whilst the minister has said that the new framework is working satisfactorily, on this side of the chamber that is not our view. Therefore, no case has been made out for the need to vary this timetable today to enable this later night sitting tonight. As the minister said, there is now not a lot of legislation before the chamber, and some of that is non-controversial and not expected to take a long time. In fact, the one I am involved in later today I doubt will take more than a few minutes. But, that has not been put to the test because before we get towards the end of the program the government joins with the minor parties to extend the sitting of the Senate. It may well be found by Thursday that this later night sitting tonight, in breach of the government's undertakings given at the beginning of this session, was unnecessary. But that will never be put to the test because the government cannot wait. It is determined to come in here and extend tonight's sitting.

I regret that we have not seen much improvement by the government in managing its program as we have moved along this path under the new timetable. If there were one or two bills that could not be dealt with it would not matter much because we are back here in just over a month, and there is very little legislation on the program that could not have waited to be dealt with at that time. In fact, that is how the new system was supposed to work—there would be a flow-over if the time for debate expired within the time frames that the government and the minor parties had set for this Senate.

We will, therefore, vote against this proposal. In our view, the case has not been made out. I regret that the numbers are such that we shall lose, but nevertheless we believe it is important to protest again at this incompetent program.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this particular motion following 20 minutes of puerile notices of motion and, in the main, we wasted 20 minutes whilst the Liberals and the Democrats argued about the Bonython by-election, their budget statements and so on. When it comes to wasting time in the chamber, we all contribute to that. Often there is a litany of opposition complaints that there are not enough ministerial statements. But when we have them they take up time which has to be made up somewhere. There have been several ministerial statements this session.
—Still not too many.

—Not enough according to Senator Hill, who would like a ministerial statement every five minutes. We are not going to have that, but ministerial statements have taken up some time. Of course, had we sat yesterday—on a public holiday—we would not have had this backlog, because we are really on an eight-day sitting pattern—four days one week, four the next. However, we had to have at least some consideration for staff and others and, of course, for the extra costs involved, so we did not sit yesterday. In the normal course of events, had we sat yesterday and had the usual two lots of four sittings, we would probably have come in on time and not been placed in a position where Senator Faulkner had to move this motion.
—If you had been able to keep the chamber going you would have finished, too.

—I will come to that in a moment, Senator Macdonald. The opposition knows that earlier in this session, from a government point of view, some legislation was ready to go but the opposition was not ready to deal with it. Senator Macdonald knows that. The opposition had not put it through the party room. These sorts of things happen; the unexpected happens. I am not criticising.
—That is correct, but it did not hold up the program.

—In the sense that we have probably spent more time on other things, it may have done so. There is no criticism here; I am just saying that the unexpected occurs from time to time. Today Senator Hill said, `We predicted all this when these changes came in'. That is a bit of a self-fulfilling prophecy. The opposition can ensure that prophecy is fulfilled any time it likes, as can any opposition, either deliberately or inadvertently, by delaying procedures in this chamber.
—There have been very few MPIs.

—I am trying to acknowledge that so we can balance up the record. On a couple of occasions in the past I have accused the opposition of deliberately delaying things. I never admitted it, but I tended to suspect that it had. The question of the quorum has been raised. The government always regrets this place being counted out. That occurred last week. It cost us one hour, not the enormous amount of time that has been implied by the opposition, which is suggesting that this motion has been introduced because we did not keep a quorum here last week. We have, obviously, taken steps to rectify that. I hope there will not be a repeat in the future.

PARA.TAB: On the question of late night sittings, I emphasise that no-one supports them. These are medium late night sittings, if you like, because we are not proposing to go past where we normally used to go. The real problem with the late night sittings was not that we sat until 10 o'clock or 10.30 p.m., but the cumulative effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are bringing the estimates committees back tomorrow morning.

—I will come to that subject in a moment, Senator, because I think it was one of the few points I should take on board to address in future deliberations. We are not proposing long, cumulative, late night sittings that I, quite frankly, admit are debilitating for people's health and general behaviour.

PARA.TAB: I come to the noting of questions. I point out that last week we extended that by 25 minutes one day because—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because your guys talked.
—I am coming to that.
—You got into it, too.

—We got an extra 25 minutes. Here is an extraordinary proposition. Time and time again at estimates committees or elsewhere when it suits—and it is in the Hansard records—I have heard members of the coalition say, `Look at the Labor people; they don't even contribute to this debate'. But the moment we jump up on the noting of questions and respond—and it is not every day; it is only on an occasional issue—it is all too hard for them. They do not like contest; they do not like combat. Instead of the opposition having a free hit for half an hour, one or two of our people jumped up and contested, and those opposite are whingeing.
—That is fine. Just allow sufficient time for it.

—When Senator Macdonald's mob was in government from 1975 to 1983 it never extended the right to note questions for half an hour a day. I am looking for some consistency here. The point made that in some way our back bench should just vacate for that half an hour and leave a free hit for those opposite is absolutely ridiculous. A more valid point could have been raised about the adjournment debate—and I must say that I have not observed it because I am not an aficionado of the adjournment debate—if there is a genuine complaint that that time is being distributed in an unfair way and not giving the opposition rights. I think that is a worthwhile point to make, and one that we can look at.
—It has been made: it has been made several times.

—It has been made. I am saying that I am quite happy to have a look at that aspect, because it is very rare that we, as a government, use the adjournment debate and I think the opposition would concede that.
—Except when you want to stop us.
—Those opposite have plenty of opportunities. There are matters of public interest on Wednesdays, and usually three or four adjournment debates, unlimited on a Monday.
—You do matters of public interest, too.

—Yes, but Senator Macdonald cannot argue, as the coalition parties have, that we do not participate properly in chamber activities, and, the moment we do, whinge about it. If we took the coalition's view to the logical extreme we would not do any government business here. We would be doing all sorts of extraneous things. Nevertheless, I do not think there is any point to be made that the noting of questions is unfair, but I do believe that we might have to look at fair allocation of adjournment debate time.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill says that this is to do with the fact that the opposition gets one minute to ask questions and we get four minutes to respond on national television. For the 50,000 people watching I guess that is fairly important. But there are always checks and balances in this process. Those opposite get hours to think up their questions, they give no notice of them, and we are supposed to represent—as I did today—$55 billion worth of government expenditure, and give a credible answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are supposed to know your portfolio.

—I have to know the health portfolio and the social security portfolio today, plus industrial relations, plus tourism, plus defence. The whole point is that it is balanced. Sure, those opposite get less time, but they get the great privilege of ambush. Those things balance out. When they get 50 per cent plus one in a general election then they can have that privilege. I will not whinge about it when we only get a minute to ask questions and they get four minutes to answer, and neither will they.

PARA.TAB: I think that Senator Faulkner is genuine in hoping that we can get back on track tonight. He has given an assurance that we will not negate the question for the adjournment tomorrow night—which not only do those opposite appreciate, but so do I do.

Finally, we get to this claim by Senator Hill that we are in some way breaching an undertaking. It was always contemplated that if the government program got behind, the adjournment would have to be negated. But we put a harder step in. Rather than just voting on the spot, we actually have to give notice of a motion and move it, like Senator Faulkner did today, which is a lot harder than rolling up on the night and suddenly negating the adjournment. There was no absolute undertaking that we would never sit past 8 o'clock, otherwise we would not have put that clause in.

What it comes down to is that Senator Faulkner is proposing to negate the adjournment tonight to try to get the program back on track. He is suggesting that if it does not get back on track we will adjourn tomorrow night at the normal time and look at absorbing some general business time on Thursday, sitting later on Thursday or sitting on Friday to get the legislative program completed.
I will take on board two or three of the things that Senator Hill said, especially regarding the allocation of time in the adjournment debate which we should give consideration to.

The final issue that I have not covered is the question of when estimates committees meet, and how long they meet. If they are meeting at the times that people have told me about, we might have to look at that. There are some difficulties. My estimates committee adjourned at 10 past 12 on the first night. We were delayed in starting because of this chamber. I have to say that when there are four departments in a night, and two have been gone through and there are just two smaller ones left, to adjourn at 11 o'clock and come back at another time is inconvenient. I think that my whole committee was pleased to bat on for an extra 70 minutes and finish before departing.

This is an exceptional year. We have six estimates committee rounds this year. That is unusual; it is an unprecedented right of opposition supervision. We have this round and a supplementary, we have further rounds in May and June, and further ones in November this year. This is the first time a government has had to go through three rounds. It is catch as catch can this time round. Certainly rational hours for estimates committees, as for this chamber, should be discussed in future. I am sure we can resolve something in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a serious issue, and it is certainly one on which I want to reinforce the statements of Senator Hill with regard to the government's management of its program. After all, we are here in the hands of the government, and most of the issues on the agenda arise as a result of government initiatives.

PARA.TAB: The minister, Senator Robert Ray, has just referred to estimates committees. It is important that we address some of these fundamental problems that are exacerbating the issue that we are dealing with today in the extension of time, and the time management of many senators in this place.

I want to illustrate that by an example of where things have got out of hand. In Estimates Committee C on Tuesday, 1 March this year—I remind the chamber that that is three weeks ago today—I raised a series of questions with regard to an $8 million allocation of funds for the Subiaco Oval in Western Australia. I made some very important points and addressed a number of fundamental questions with regard to both the bureaucratic and the political decision-making process of that $8 million allocation.

Naturally, there were political overtones. There were links to Mr Dawkins, the then Treasurer; there were links to the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe; there were links to Dr Carmen Lawrence who, at the time we were inquiring into, was the Labor Premier of Western Australia. Maybe for government reasons, and because an election involving Dr Lawrence was coming up in Western Australia in the intervening period, the government would not provide any of that information to Estimates Committee C. I was seeking in particular—and I refer to page C166 and onwards of the Hansard for 1 March—a lot of information that required the minister, and I think it was Senator Crowley on that occasion, and the chairman of the committee, Senator Reynolds, to pursue with Minister Howe access to ministerial correspondence.

When the estimates committee again met on Thursday, 17 March, none of that information had been provided. I sought it again in more detail. It was very obvious from the information that was given to us by departmental officers that the information had been tendered to Mr Howe's office. All of the correspondence that I was seeking between Mr Howe, Mr Dawkins and Dr Lawrence had very important overtones and, as it turned out from some other departmental information that flowed, an implication that also linked the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to this area. It became obvious that there was probably a good deal of correspondence. This is a fundamental issue of an $8 million expenditure where the books were obviously cooked between Mr Dawkins, Mr Howe, the Prime Minister and Dr Lawrence.

Now, three weeks later, Senator Reynolds and I are trying to reach an accord with regard to a meeting time for Estimates Committee C. It was canvassed that we would have to meet early tomorrow morning or late tomorrow night. Then I heard through the secretary of the committee that we could not possibly have it on Thursday morning because that would conflict with the Labor Party Caucus. I find it insulting when instructions come telling us that we cannot have a meeting because it might just happen to coincide with the Labor Party Caucus.

TALK.START.PARA: —What meeting?

—I am only relaying information that has been put to me—whether they are Labor Party committee meetings or not. This is the process of management where obviously the government is embarrassed about this information with regard to Mr Keating, Mr Dawkins, Dr Lawrence—the whole lot of them. The accusation has been made that this all relates to a new job for Mr Dawkins on the Western Australian Football Commission. Naturally, therefore, the government wants to spin all of this out until Thursday at the latest. This parliament will rise for another five or six weeks, the issue will not surface, and it will not receive proper consideration through the appropriate forum of this Senate.

PARA.TAB: The program is out of whack, and tonight we are being forced to consider other legislation because the Greens, the Democrats and the Labor Party have obviously cooked up a deal. But they are not giving proper consideration to the issues that should be evolving. I am pointing out only one particular issue: this Subiaco Oval con job where $8 million has been going round in little circles for nearly three years and where surreptitious deals have been done between Mr Keating, Mr Dawkins, Dr Lawrence and Mr Howe. We cannot get the information from Senator Crowley, and we cannot get it from Senator Reynolds under the committee system.

As I said in the committee the other night, there is obviously camouflage and subterfuge with regard to this very important project. It smells. We want to deal with it, but we are being forced off to other estimates committee meetings at dawn tomorrow morning. As Senator Patterson said, there was a request for one committee to meet this morning at 6.30. How ridiculous! That is then compounded in other areas of the committee. It proves that government management is totally out of control. When it comes to a cover-up, the government is the supreme expert at trying to rig the agenda and at trying to control the flow of information.

There will not be any time for a debate on this issue if, as I suspect, this correspondence shows that there probably should be a much more substantive debate in this chamber during this week's program on such an important issue. I certainly stand with Senator Hill in raising points of very serious objection on this particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support my colleagues on this matter. I would also like to make the point—and Senator Murphy would know this—that there was an attempt made to have the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure meet at 6.30 in the morning one day last week. That was—
—I did not complain about that.
—Senator Murphy did not complain about it and I did not complain about it. I am just informing the Senate that an attempt was made.

PARA.TAB: Before he left the chamber, Senator Robert Ray mentioned that we have used the excuse that the opposition's party room has not dealt with legislation. That is right. A heap of legislation was introduced into the Senate and into the House of Representatives after our final party meeting last year. We could not be expected to have done it before we came back here. That is a moot point that was made by the government, but there was a valid reason why we did not do it.

I put the programs together of a morning and I know that the government did not have legislation ready at the beginning of this year, either. Many times the government's legislation was not ready and it used up time by bringing in the registration of senators' interests. That could have waited quite some time, because after all—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been around for eight years.

—In the House of Representatives the government has had plenty of time to deal with members' interests. A lot of members in the House of Representatives are doing a big cover-up regarding their spouses. I mentioned this in the debate here last week and the Australian Democrats did not take any part. But, lo and behold, I read in the press at the weekend that the Democrats suddenly discovered some members of the House of Representatives did not know what their wives were doing so far as financial matters were concerned. All of a sudden the Democrats found something to make a noise about; yet they did not take part in the debate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray said that members of the government should take turn in taking note of answers. He and a few others on the government side of the chamber must have a short memory. The concept of taking note of answers was introduced to let the opposition have its say following question time. Question time is loaded in favour of the government, even with the time limits. Senator Jones knows that; he took part in the deliberations when this half-hour was introduced.

Senator Ray and everybody else on the government side forget that we gave up urgency motions and MPIs. Only one such issue has been raised since the introduction of the new timetable. The government is using up the Senate's time with the taking note of answers. I cannot see why the opposition should not use the time we are allowed every day to raise urgency motions and MPIs. We can do that quite easily.

All in all, the government has wasted time in insisting on senators' interests being debated. It could have waited. But now we are going back to the old situation. The government will use up the other parts of the new sitting times such as the lunch break, starting at 9.30, and whatever, but it still wants more time at the end of the day.

When I left here last Thursday evening the Democrats were not going to support this motion, but all of a sudden—surprise! surprise!—this morning we found out that they will support it. They are saying, `Oh, the poor government has not got any legislation through'. Whose fault is that? The government need not have worried about senators' interests; it could have had the legislative program ready. The Government Whip should have had the numbers in here when the quorum was called. There are lots of reasons why the government is behind with its program.

Is it in concrete that we will not sit late tomorrow night? From the way Senator Ray put it, I thought he was keeping his options open. He can reassure me if he wants to. I thought I heard him say that if we are back on track we might not have to sit on Wednesday night. I also thought I heard him say that if we are on track we might not sit Thursday night. But I will not make any arrangements to go home on Friday because no-one on the government side has ruled out sitting on Friday. I support my colleagues on this matter. It is a disgrace that we have to interfere with these sitting times when they were voted in because they were so good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again I want to congratulate Senator Robert Ray on his well-oiled, calm, apparently reasoned and apparently reasonable address. The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—On behalf of the President, and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 27 of 1993-94: Report on ministerial portfolios—Autumn sittings 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's report No. 27 runs across the whole range of ministerial portfolios. All of these reports, in one form or another, have already been presented to the parliament but in this report the Auditor-General has dealt with some follow-up matters. He says:

The audit report on the Aggregate Financial Statement prepared by the Minister for Finance for the year ended 30 June 1993 was qualified on the basis that audit reports on underlying departmental financial statements had been qualified on matters which were material in the context of the Aggregate.
Audit reports on fifteen departmental financial statements were qualified.

In the non-departmental area, six statutory authorities and three companies were qualified. The qualifications related to uncertainty of sale values of assets and liabilities; inadequate accounts and records; and accounting and disclosure aspects involving breaches of legislation and accounting standards.
The key findings of this audit inspection were:

Problems still exist with the inclusion of supplementary information on certain assets and liabilities in departmental financial statements. The financial statements of five departments were qualified on the grounds of inadequate accounts and records of assets.
Outstanding accounting issues continue with a number of departments regarding the validity of benefit payments and substantiation of revenues due to the Commonwealth.
There were numerous procedural and controlled breakdowns together with minor and technical non-compliance with Commonwealth laws.

There remains considerable scope for more timely preparation of financial information subject to audit, together with a need to improve accounts and records and control systems that produce financial information.

I do not want to deal at great length with all these matters that the Auditor-General has raised. However, I want to draw a couple of them to the attention of the Senate. The first one relates to the explosives factory at Maribyrnong. The audit report states:

The report of a preliminary study of Defence's procedures associated with the closure of the Explosives Factory Maribyrnong has commented on Defence's expenditure of some $26m on facilities to produce nitroester and rocket motor propellants, and on procedures to clear and decontaminate the factory site for future development. The report notes that remediation of the site will be expensive and that it will be many years before a suitable use for the site can be determined.

This has turned into quite a saga. I think the Senate will be concerned about several aspects of this matter. In the first place, I refer to the contamination of the site. This is of major significance. As the Auditor-General reports:

PARA.TAB: The Department valued the disposal properties at market value of $231m.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the market value of that Maribyrnong site. The Auditor-General continued:
Market value represents the amount the Department would expect to receive on disposal less selling costs including those costs associated with making the property saleable.

Information was not available to the Auditor-General, however, which would allow these costs of making this site saleable to be quantified. However, the Auditor-General says it is possible that these costs could exceed the reported property values. As I said, the reported property value is $231 million, but the costs of decontaminating this land could, according to the Auditor-General, exceed that property value. That is an incredible cost. The cost to decontaminate this land could exceed $231 million. The audit report continued:

The ANAO considered that the value of these properties reported by the Department did not reflect the true market value as it did not make allowance for decontamination costs of those properties. The Department advised it did not provide an estimate of the likely costs because relevant information had not been obtained or the uncertainties involved precluded a reliable estimate being formulated. Accordingly, the ANAO was unable to determine the extent of the costs not reflected in the financial statement.

This kind of cost is, to my mind, absolutely incredible. In fact, the whole question of the Maribyrnong explosives factory astounds me because quite apart from the question of decontamination is the question of some extraordinary expenditures just before the factory moved. To complete the matter of site clearance and contamination, I note that the Auditor-General's report states:
. . . At the time of closing the Explosives Factory Maribyrnong—
which was in December 1990, as I recall—

there were some 500 building on the 92 hectare site. The site and buildings were contaminated by chemicals after many years of explosives production. The objective was to clear the site of contaminated buildings that presented a hazard. Preliminary studies have given some indication of site contamination. Demolition work has had to take account of this and heritage considerations. Buildings assessed as having heritage value will be examined for their level of contamination. Some 200 buildings have been demolished, and more will be demolished in 1994.

. . . The extent of contamination of the ground is still not known but qualitative studies are under way. The Department said that studies so far indicate that the site does not present a danger externally and is unlikely to present a human or ecological health risk to its surroundings.

. . . A proposed second stage of studies will investigate the drainage system and assess the extent of contamination of the rest of the site quantitatively to help in estimating the remediation cost. It is not yet possible to estimate this cost or when remediation will be complete. It seems, however, that remediation will be expensive and that it will be many years before a suitable future use for the site can be determined.

This is quite extraordinary. Not only does the government not know how much it is going to cost to fix up this contaminated site, but it also does not know how long it is going to take and what the ultimate outcome of those attempts to fix up the site will be. The fact that it could cost more than the estimated value of $230 million is quite extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: It is also extraordinary to note that early in 1993 the audit office made a preliminary study of the procedures of the Department of Defence associated with the closure of the explosives factory in Maribyrnong in Melbourne. The Auditor-General's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Explosives had been manufactured at the site since 1912 but by 1989 the facilities were regarded as out of date and too close to residential areas. Production capability was moved to facilities at Salisbury and elsewhere.

. . . Two issues arose during the preliminary study. One was the expenditure of some $26m on facilities to produce nitroester and rocket motor propellants that has provided little value. The other was the delay in action to clear and decontaminate the factory site.
This production of nitroester was an extraordinary waste of money. The Auditor-General's report states:

. . . Plant to produce nitroester was ordered in 1987. (Nitroester is used in the production of rocket propellants, Otto fuel for torpedoes, etc.) In February 1989 the then Minister for Defence announced that the factory would close before December 1990 and that the buildings would be demolished. After the Minister's announcement the Department continued with the acquisition of the nitroester plant, which was delivered in May 1989 . . .

I remind honourable senators that the decision was made in February 1989 to close the factory but the department went on with the delivery of the nitroester plant in May 1989 and installed it not in the new facility at Salisbury but in the old factory at Maribyrnong that was going to be closed down. The report states:

. . . After operating the plant for only three months, the Department transferred it in February 1991 to Salisbury where it was operated for only six months (September 1991-March 1992). The plant has since been scrapped. The cost of the purchase, installation and transfer of the plant was $5.2m.
That was absolutely and totally wasted. The report continues:

. . . The Salisbury facility was established to accommodate the Nulka Project, which had been developed at the Maribyrnong factory. (Nulka is a naval rocket-powered hovering decoy.) Between 1987 and 1992 the Department outlaid $22.3m through the Maribyrnong factory to establish the Salisbury facility. Of this amount some $10.8 million was spent from 1987 to 1990 on cast composite rocket propellant facilities for the Nulka Project and $11.5m was spent from 1990 to 1992 to establish a cast double base propellant facility for rocket motors in Ikara and Seacat missiles.

. . . It was announced in mid-1992 that the Salisbury facility would be closed. There was no demand for the rocket motors. Although the Navy decided in March 1991 to stop using Ikara missiles, the Department continued to transfer rocket production facilities to Salisbury. Interest in Nulka declined; the Department will relocate the Nulka capability to Mulwala at further cost.
The Auditor-General says that it seemed to the ANAO:

. . . the expenditure on plant to produce nitroester and facilities to produce rocket propellants provided little value to the Commonwealth and could have been avoided, at least partly, with forethought and better planning and coordination . . .
. . . The Department said that in hindsight it might be seen as unnecessary to have purchased and installed the nitroester plant.
The department responded to the Auditor-General and has stated:

The decisions taken by Defence in relation to establishing production facilities for nitroester and rocket motor propellants were based on the best information available at the time. Subsequent changes in operational requirements which resulted in the withdrawal from service of the Ikara and Seacat weapons systems significantly reduced the need for the facilities but it was not possible to foresee this at the time of the original decisions. Nor was it practicable to alter the course of action in progress to establish facilities at the stage the change in operational requirements became known.

I must say that that looks quite extraordinary. It seems to me that the Auditor-General has uncovered once again in his particularly useful way some curious decisions within the bureaucratic structure. I commend him for doing so.

PARA.TAB: There are just a couple of other remarks I would like to make briefly about the Auditor-General's report. One of them relates to the Australian Pork Corporation. I give notice that I will be paying more attention to this matter at an appropriate time. The Auditor-General's report on the audit of the accounts and records of the corporation referred to the fact that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . During the year the corporation incurred approximately $40 000 for legal costs in relation to the industry's appeal to the Federal Court in respect to findings regarding imports of Canadian pigmeat. Of this expense, an amount of almost $28 000 was in breach of the Pig Industry Act as it was a variance from the expenses included in the annual operational plan approved by the Minister.

. . . The Corporation has since been advised by the Minister that he is unable to sanction the Corporation funding the Federal Court action. The Corporation is continuing to seek Ministerial approval for the expense.
I must say that I hope, if that requires a cabinet decision, that a declaration of interest will be made on the matter by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: The final matter I would like to raise relates to the audit of the Australian Taxation Office, which I would like to deal with at length at another time. I want to mention in passing that it is curious to note that one of the matters that the audit office found to be unsatisfactory was the use by members of the tax office of the Australian Government credit card. The Auditor-General has said:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a number of unsatisfactory matters relating to credit cards including:
.inadequate descriptions on sales vouchers which prevented verification of items purchased and no supporting documentation that goods and services had been received; and
.monthly reconciliations of the credit card settlement account which were not always completed.

There may be some taxpayers who would be very interested to know that in its own administration the tax office, which takes such a strong position on the verification of credit card accounts that it will not regard monthly credit card statements as evidence of expenditure and requires the little yellow slips, has not satisfied the Auditor-General in respect of descriptions on sale vouchers and unsatisfactory reconciliation of the credit card settlement account. This is perhaps a whimsy that might appeal to those taxpayers who have found their deductions denied simply because they provided credit card monthly statements. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Parer, I present report No. 330, Review of Auditor-General's Reports, May 1991-September 1992, by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Report 330, Review of Auditor-General's Reports, May 1991—September 1992 details the Committee's review of 72 audit reports.
The review was conducted in accordance with the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, which requires the Committee to examine all reports of the Auditor-General.

As well as representing the fulfilment of a statutory obligation, the review on which this report is based has given the Committee an opportunity to re-visit a series of audits which had been conducted some years ago. With the perspective of time, the Committee has been able to identify issues which have not, in the intervening years, been properly addressed by the audited agency.

The Committee has not canvassed in detail all of the issues raised in the audit reports: to have done so would have gone over ground already well covered by the Auditor-General, and would have delayed considerably the tabling of this report.
Instead, the Committee has focused on the recommendations contained in the audit reports. We have surveyed and checked the responses given by each of the audited agencies.

In the vast majority of cases the audited agencies have agreed with the recommendations contained in the audit reports, and have taken appropriate, timely and effective remedial action. In these cases the Committee has made no comment.

The Committee has commented only in those cases where the agency response has been inappropriate, tardy or ineffective. Most of the recommendations therefore are aimed at encouraging agencies to complete actions taken in response to a particular audit report. However, I wish to draw attention to two recommendations which have wider implications.

The first concerns internal audit. The Auditor-General had recommended that the Department of Finance should develop better in-house knowledge and expertise in the area of internal audit so that it could help to improve standards in public sector internal auditing.
The Department of Finance disagrees, maintaining that, in a devolved environment, it is inappropriate for it to have a broad role in assisting agencies to develop expertise in internal audit.

The Committee supports the view expressed by the Auditor-General and has recommended that the Department of Finance take a broader and more active role in improving internal audit standards in Commonwealth agencies. The Committee believes this role fits squarely with Finance's policy and program responsibilities.

A second recommendation I wish to draw attention to, concerns the mandate of the Auditor-General. The Committee notes that the Auditor-General has for some time sought to have himself appointed as the auditor for ANUTECH, a wholly owned subsidiary company of the ANU.

This is consistent with recommendations contained in the Committee's Report 296, The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament, which called for the Auditor-General to be the auditor for all statutory authorities, government owned companies and government business enterprises. Moreover, in December 1990, the Government announced its agreement to this principle.

The Committee endorses the Auditor-General's view that full public accountability to the Parliament of ANUTECH is not assured under the current auditing arrangements. Accordingly, we have recommended that the Auditor-General be appointed as ANUTECH's auditor.

Although Report 330 is necessarily brief in the consideration it gives to the audit reports, the process of checking agency responses has been valuable in itself. Many agencies have been required to report to the Committee, in some cases more than once, on their progress in implementing the Auditor-General's recommendations.

The Committee regards its review of reports of the Auditor-General as an important part of its work and intends to table the results of its examinations on a regular basis. On occasions this will result in compilation reports, like Report 330, but on other occasions the Committee will review and report on individual audit reports.

In addition to this statutory review process, the House of Representatives has, over the last decade, developed the practice of referring some audit reports to its standing committees and to certain joint committees.

The Committee acknowledges that the referral of some audit reports to other committees is appropriate in some circumstances—for example, where an audit report is relevant to a subject already being considered by another committee, or where an audit report deals with an issue in which another committee has developed a particular expertise.

However, the requirement to review described in the Public Accounts Committee Act is not satisfied by the referral of an audit report to another committee. It is the Committee's intention to examine all reports by the Auditor-General which are tabled in the Parliament. Although the Committee is conscious of the need to avoid unnecessary duplication, it will examine audit reports which have been referred to other committees. It is anticipated that, at times, this examination will show that another committee has reviewed or is reviewing the major issues identified in the audit report. At other times, the Committee may decide that further review is needed.

The reports of the Auditor-General make an essential contribution to parliamentary and public scrutiny of the Executive. Report 330 will remind agencies that the process of scrutiny continues beyond the tabling of an audit report.

As honourable senators would be aware, there has been some heated debate recently about the need to strengthen the mandate of the Auditor-General and take steps to ensure his independence from the Executive. I welcome this debate and remind the Senate that these issues have been of interest to the JCPA. Indeed they were at the heart of the Committee's Report 296, which was tabled in March 1989.

I urge the Government to take advantage of the present opportunity to incorporate in its proposed financial management and audit legislation those recommendations from Report 296 which it had previously rejected.

On behalf of the Committee, I would like to thank the secretariat for their work on the review. I would also like to acknowledge the contribution made by other officers from the House of Representatives who helped in the initial analysis of the 72 audit reports reviewed in Report 330. Finally, I acknowledge the Australian National Audit Office for their assistance during this review, and, of course, without whom this review would not be possible.
I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report which I have tabled deals with technical training and other facilities at HMAS Cerberus, Western Port, Victoria. HMAS Cerberus is the major training establishment for the Royal Australian Navy and is located on Western Port Bay, Victoria, some 60 kilometres south-east of Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: The 1991 Defence Force structure review endorsed by the Commonwealth government foreshadowed the closure and transfer of the technical training establishment at HMAS Nirimba west of Sydney. At the invitation of the Hon. L. Lieberman MP, member for Indi, the committee inspected the army college of TAFE at Bonegilla, which was one of the alternative locations considered for training by the Department of Defence. Although impressed by the facilities at Bonegilla, the committee concurs with the decision made by the Department of Defence, following a survey conducted for them by Kinhill Engineers, to transfer technical training to HMAS Cerberus.

The transfer of technical training from HMAS Nirimba to HMAS Cerberus necessitates the provision of additional facilities to enable effective training to continue. Existing facilities and services at HMAS Cerberus date back to the early 1920s. However, a number of facilities are more modern or have been upgraded. This proposal provides for technical training facilities, replacement of those facilities where upgrading is not economical, expansion of facilities unable to cope with increased demand and new facilities for services operating from temporary and inadequate accommodation.

The scope of the work provides for continuous functioning of the base throughout the construction period and includes a health centre, technical training classrooms and workshops, indoor swimming pool, gymnasium extension, motor transport compound and engineering services.

The committee viewed the medical and dental services which are presently provided from 18 separate buildings. The majority of these buildings are being utilised for functions for which they were neither originally designed nor adequately constructed. The committee agrees with a comment made by the Minister for Defence, the Hon. Senator Robert Ray, when, at a Senate estimates committee hearing in September 1991, he described the facility as the `most disgraceful Defence facility I have seen in Australia'. The committee commends the personnel at HMAS Cerberus for working under such conditions.

The question of waste water management was raised by the committee at the public hearing, and the Department of Defence gave the committee a verbal undertaking to carry out a study of the potential for the re-use of waste water at HMAS Cerberus. That has been the attitude of the committee on a number of issues. The committee, therefore, recommended in its report that such a survey be carried out. However, last Friday the committee received a report on recycling of second class water, which has been carried out by Kinhill Engineers for the Department of Defence. This report concluded that the cost of developing and operating recycled water irrigation systems is high, and the implementation of such schemes will not result in an overall cost saving through the reduction of relatively small volumes of first class water. The committee commends the Department of Defence for speedily taking action on its recommendation and assures it that the committee will study the report in detail.

The committee commends the Department of Defence on the regular energy audits of its establishments and recommends that it be advised on the implementation of the recommendations of the energy audit recently conducted at HMAS Cerberus. The estimated cost of the technical training and other facilities at HMAS Cerberus is $45.5 million at April 1993 prices. I commend the report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Chapman had moved by way of amendment:
