TALK.START.PARA: —We return to the debate on the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill, which is essentially a machinery bill and which allows a couple of alterations, keeping in mind the government's nomination of a particular person, namely, Justice Deirdre O'Connor to be appointed as President of the Industrial Relations Commission. This legislation is particularly related to that appointment. As such, it allows a current judge of a court created by parliament to be president, and not, as the legislation presently allows, just a person who has previously been a judge. It ensures that a judge's salary and conditions are not reduced or affected by such an appointment as president. The legislation allows the first president, Deirdre O'Connor, to be appointed after its passage. It allows that first president to be appointed for just five years, with subsequent appointments to age 65 as before.

PARA.TAB: The matter of a five-year appointment would normally be of considerable concern because it raises the potential for governments to undermine the president's independence and thereby the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission itself. I say that it would normally be of great concern, but that concern is alleviated entirely by the fact that it will be applicable to the first president to be appointed and therefore it does not establish a precedent.

In this chamber we can establish laws to change legislation for each particular case. That does not establish a precedent; it allows individual cases to be considered on their merit. If a future change was to be made—as has been suggested by some critics of this legislation—it would occur not as a result of a precedent but after a full deliberation in this place. Full parliamentary scrutiny is what is required for the amendment of any legislation.

Therefore it does not create a precedent; it creates a particular application. We still have the opportunity to judge legislation on its merits. The Australian Democrats have no difficulty with this particular legislation. The government's professed aim is to make senior appointments from outside what is known as the industrial relations club and we welcome that move. Regardless of which interest group in society the appointee comes from, in a body such as the Industrial Relations Commission all new appointees will need to work extremely hard to gain the confidence not only of their colleagues but also of those on whose behalf they are passing judgment. That would apply no matter who was appointed.

There is no reason to doubt that Justice O'Connor will rise to the occasion—as she has done in other appointments, such as on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Her track record demonstrates she has a capacity for intelligence and energy, and independence. An independent point of view is the most important characteristic here, and that has been displayed in former appointments. They are the sorts of qualities that the President of the Industrial Relations Commission will need to display.

I will just say in passing that Mr Iain Ross will be a fine addition to the commission because he brings with him, as a vice-president of part of the Industrial Relations Commission, particular expertise in the area for which he will be responsible. He will have a key role in making that division work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh no! It's a disaster.

—No matter what appointments have been made in the past there have been almost poetic cries of indignation from various quarters, whether from the present government when previous appointments were made or from the coalition when this government has made other appointments. The cries seem orchestrated and poetic; they are contrived and have virtually been rehearsed to the point of being refined and almost predictable. We have seen such orchestrations before. Those who have argued against the appointments to such senior posts usually have fallen flat on their faces because the capacity of the appointees has been demonstrated to them.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is proposing an amendment to the second reading. The amendment says that the opposition deplores the government's incompetence in industrial relations and accuses it of stacking the commission's senior posts with unionists.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a terrible appointment—he's a union operative.

—My first reaction to the claim that senior commission posts have been stacked with union officials is that it is misleading to attach such weight to the origins of commission members. Once people are appointed to the commission they tend to be influenced more by their obligation to serve the public interest than by their past allegiances. For instance, I am quite certain that Mr Iain Ross will act with the intelligence and impartiality that is required in his new post.

PARA.TAB: It is ironic that the reverse allegation was made not so long ago by Mr Bill Kelty of the ACTU. He said that the commission was loaded with former employer advocates. It was good enough in the past for Mr Kelty to make such an accusation. Of course the accusation was unfounded.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is not. There has to be a balance.

—Did I hear somebody talking about balance? The Democrats do not dispute that the commission needs to be broadly represented. I would even use the word `balanced', now that it has been introduced into the argument. But it does not refer only to former employer representatives or former employee representatives, but also, for example, to gender balance. Taking into account all the considerations, the appointments that have been made by Minister Brereton are a step in the right direction. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating. To make assertions and assumptions now is not only naive but, I suggest, ignores the precedents of decisions that have been made by the commission—and the criticisms of them.

PARA.TAB: What matters ultimately is not the make-up of the commission but the decisions. The time to criticise will be when the decisions are before us. The late Justice Madden may once have been an employer advocate but his last national wage case decision, when handed down, quite properly gave priority to social justice considerations. We expect the new commission to bring the same wisdom and independence to bear in the ground-breaking work before it. We oppose the amendment to the second reading; and we support the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1994 and support the remarks of my colleague Senator Chapman and the amendment that he has moved. This bill makes provision for the appointment of a judge as President of the Industrial Relations Commission. Justice Deirdre O'Connor has had a distinguished career. At present she is a judge in the Federal Court and President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. She was also chair of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for a time. However, there is nothing in her record to suggest that she has had any significant experience in the complex and difficult area of industrial relations. Honourable senators may be aware that the Industrial Relations Act specifically indicates that the appointee to the position of president should have `skills and experience in the field of industrial relations'.

PARA.TAB: As far as I can ascertain, Justice Deirdre O'Connor's experience in the area of industrial relations is extremely limited. It is confined essentially to workers' compensation where the issues involved inevitably do not deal with the collective relations between employers and employees. It is a measure of the arrogance of this government that whereas we are passing this legislation through the parliament purely to assist the appointment of Justice O'Connor, the government is unwilling to acknowledge in this bill that by the standards of the current act—its own act which it has previously passed through this parliament—it appears that Justice O'Connor is not qualified for this task.

Presumably the Governor-General is going to be advised that Justice Deirdre O'Connor has a high level of experience in industrial relations. The government will have to advise him that. The government should change the act to allow the appointment of someone like Justice O'Connor, without the necessary experience—if that is the way the government wishes to go—or the Governor-General should press the executive council for further information on her industrial relations experience.

This is not just a debating point. By not amending the legislation this way the government exposes Justice O'Connor to being disqualified from office at a future date, possibly by the High Court. One can easily contemplate that in a bitter industrial relations dispute where emotions are running very high a declaration could be sought by parties to this dispute, who may believe they will be in receipt of an unfavourable determination, claiming to the High Court that Justice Deirdre O'Connor has not been properly appointed. I also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the announcement of the appointment has been made before the legislation is through the parliament and before the Governor-General has had a chance to consider the recommendation of the government. This is but another example of an arrogant break with tradition, when the Governor-General announces the appointments of high government office.

There are strong reasons for this protocol, not the least being that the appointees are seen to be independent. There are a number of people on the Federal Court who have a more detailed understanding and, hence, a far greater claim to this position than Justice O'Connor would appear to have. Such people include Justice Keely, Justice Gray, Justice Ryan or Justice Northrop. Possibly they were approached by Minister Brereton—I do not know. However, it has to be said that there was no press speculation encouraged by the minister's office about possible offers to these and other distinguished judges.

In industrial relations circles there is widespread criticism of the government for its failure to consult about this appointment. I am sorry that this point was not picked up by Senator Bell in his remarks. The last three presidents of the commission—Sir Richard Kirby, Sir John Moore and Barry Maddern—had a wealth of experience to bring to the institution. Maddern struggled hard and manfully to maintain the independence of the institution but, as we all know, he was treated shabbily by Mr Kelty and the government for his efforts.

Justice O'Connor—I heard Senator Bell's remarks and the hopes that he expressed—may turn out to be a great president of the commission. I wish her well. But I would be less than frank if I did not state that at present, based on her level of experience, she is clearly the odd president out—and I am referring to the other three presidents. There is an argument put to me by people involved in this area that industrial relations is a jurisdiction where subtlety and a deep knowledge of industrial relations history is important in the often highly charged atmosphere in which cases are heard. I certainly hope that Justice O'Connor has these skills.

All previous appointments saw the post of President of the Industrial Relations Commission as the pinnacle of their careers. This bill makes it a comparatively short-term assignment. Justice O'Connor has been appointed for a fixed period only. Why? The presidency of the commission is not a life sentence. Justice O'Connor could leave at any time—in two, five or 10 years. The government has not explained why it is necessary to create this special arrangement. Senator Faulkner is smiling. I am interested to hear his remarks. Perhaps he could answer the question about the five-year term and what is so special about it.

As is usual with this government, there was no consultation with employers prior to the announcement. I am sorry that Senator Bell did not make that comment. It is important in this area that the commission enjoys the confidence of all parties. When employers and their views are not only ignored, which is bad enough, but are not even given the courtesy of an opportunity to consult with the government, it is a very poor start indeed.

Justice O'Connor will have a mighty task to convince employers in this country that the court will provide industrial relations justice without fear or favour. The plain fact of the matter—I again listened very carefully to Senator Bell's comments—is that the presidential members of the commission have been stacked with ACTU operatives: Jan Marsh, Alan Boulton, Ian Watson and Jenny Acton are already presidential members; Iain Ross, as has been mentioned, has just been appointed. All these individuals come directly from the office of Bill Kelty. If it is not so important whether these people have a union background or an employer's background, why are all these major appointments coming straight out of the ACTU? Frankly, the government and the unions feel it is important and we in this Senate should express concern about it.

Mr Acting Deputy President, with your interest in industrial relations you will remember that Jenny Acton got her position by deciding not to contest the ALP preselection for the seat of Hotham. Honourable senators will recall that that seat was given to Simon Crean. What a small world it is. Of course, that is not to say that these appointees are precluded from carrying out their tasks in a thoroughly professional fashion. I understand that Alan Boulton, for example, has established a reputation for impartiality and is eminently well qualified for the position he currently holds. I point out to Senator Bell that I am not opposed to the appointment of union people, but we need union people of quality and union people who are prepared to establish their independence. Even Phil Gude, the Victorian industrial relations minister, observed that Boulton had served as President of the Victorian Industrial Relations Commission with integrity and professionalism.

By the standards of the Labor cronies act—the overriding law which governs the activities of the Keating administration—it has to be said that Iain Ross, the new vice-president in charge of enterprise agreements, is superbly qualified, having worked with both Mr Keating and Mr Kelty. He has the double. Indeed, a number of commentators consider the vice-presidential role to be more powerful and influential in the commission than even the presidential position, to which Justice O'Connor has been appointed. The result of the government's legislation in this area is to force work into the bargaining division, which Iain Ross, late of the ACTU, controls.

The AIRC should not be in a position, as the ACTU is, where the secretary makes the running and the president is the mouthpiece. Justice O'Connor has the ultimate responsibility for the commission, but she will have no direct control over one of the key areas. Hence, this vice-presidential appointment greatly adds to the problems that Justice O'Connor now has in restoring the credibility of the commission.

There are approximately 17 presidential members of the commission in all. I point out to Senator Bell that only two members come from business backgrounds and two from government backgrounds. As I have said, the preponderance of federal government appointees to the commission comes from trade union backgrounds. Senator Bell—given his often expressed concern for small business, which I do not dispute—would have served the community better if he had drawn the attention of his particular concern to this stacking of the commission.

Under previous administrations, Liberal and Labor, there was a genuine attempt to establish a balanced commission that could attract widespread support from the community and, indeed, all sides of politics. Under the Hawke and Keating governments, this tradition has been cast aside. The commission, through appointments and the Industrial Relations Reform Act, has in effect been converted to an arm of government and of the ACTU in an attempt to make it do Keating and Kelty's bidding. I therefore stress that Justice O'Connor and her other commission members have a truly mighty task to demonstrate independence from the government and the ACTU. Their efforts will be closely watched by the coalition.

As I said, neither business nor the states were consulted in this appointment. The changes to industrial relations make it essential that the states be consulted on appointments. There is no doubt that the commission's role has been greatly strengthened by the recent change to the Industrial Relations Act, giving the commission power to set minimum terms and conditions of employment for all Australian workers, not just those covered by federal awards. There will be increasing importance attached to test cases run in the commission on such matters as parental leave, termination and redundancy.

Mr Justice Boulton, in the Australian Journal of Labor Law, argues that there has been widespread acceptance of the need for cooperation and coordination between different industrial relations systems. The Commonwealth, as the dominant player, must exercise considerable care and restraint in making further changes to the system and in making appointments to the commission. In this context, the failure to consult with the states prior to making a present appointment is not a welcome development. If the Commonwealth wishes to establish its bona fides in relation to a more coordinated and cooperative national set of arrangements governing industrial relations, it must take the initiative in promoting greater trust and confidence in those parts of the national system over which it has exclusive control.

It also needs to be remembered that this government and the present ACTU leadership have done more to damage the standing and reputation of the AIRC than any other government in our history. Honourable senators will recall the Staples affair, the controversy over commission pay, a tax on the commission by Keating and Kelty after the 1991 national wage case, and the stacking of trade union people onto the commission. And who could forget the resignation of the former trade union leader and commissioner, Ken Turbet, who said that he had had a gutful of government and ACTU attacks on the commission.

There is no doubt that in the not too distant future Justice O'Connor will have the opportunity to demonstrate that the commission over which she now presides is one that will maintain its independence and integrity and will judge cases on their merits and not simply endorse government-ACTU proposals. She would do a great deal to restore confidence in the commission if she gave a clear message to the government that what she wanted was a balanced and independent commission.

The government changes to the AIRC are an attempt to bend this institution to union and government dictates. The government, forever proving that it is the industrial arm of the trade union movement, has met all of Kelty's demands over the last decade or so to extend union power and privilege within the Australian community. Just think of the list: compulsory amalgamations; compulsory superannuation; overriding state government laws through the aggressive use of ILO conventions; huge amounts of government grants to trade unions; and of course a vast range of jobs in strategic positions being given to union representatives.

In relation to the AIRC, the government has been more than happy to follow Mr Kelty's bidding. Yet the paradox remains: every effort to buttress the power and privilege of unions only seems to make them feel more insecure. I point out to Labor senators that the ultimate security of the union movement lies not within the laws which this parliament or any other parliament may pass; nor does it lie in the ability of Bill Kelty to stack key institutions. The security of the union movement lies in the hearts and minds of Australians. And the plain fact of the matter is that increasing numbers of Australians are refusing to join trade unions.

After a decade in power, all the ALP-ACTU government has delivered is massive unemployment. Of course, having prevented major reforms to the economy, Kelty and Keating have left Australian workers exposed to further economic adversity. Kelty has treated other players—key institutions and state governments—with contempt. I wonder whether he is worried that other governments in other times may make use of the precedence that he has established. Mr Kelty's attitude reminds me of the East Germans: they constructed the Berlin Wall and for decades worked hard to make it more secure and more impregnable; yet in 1989 the whole structure came tumbling down.

In 1994 the attitudes of Mr Kelty seem more and more irrelevant. If the AIRC as it is presently constructed turns out to be simply another arm of the Kelty machine and the government, we can be assured that public support and respect, which are essential to any key institution, will collapse. Justice O'Connor and her colleagues must now establish their independence. If they do not, I make this prediction: this parliament will be debating industrial relations reform bills relating to the AIRC in the years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1994 for just a few minutes of the Senate's time to support what my colleagues Senator Chapman and Senator Kemp have already said. The key thing about industrial relations is the perception of the business community about what is happening in that world and what impact it will have on the long-term economy of this nation.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make this afternoon is that, even though this is just a minor machinery bill to amend the substantive bill which went through the parliament in December, it does not encourage people to invest in Australia. In fact, it is another minor irritant on the investment scene here. I have said in the Senate several times that there is an investment crisis here right now. The level of investment in Australia for the last two years has been the lowest ever by business for over 30 years, and the investment in plant and equipment is the lowest ever since World War II—over 40 years.

Last week we saw the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) threatening business by saying that, unless it lifted the level of investment, there may be an outburst of wage claims by the union movement—by the ACTU—against the business community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why shouldn't they?

—What an extraordinary outburst! If we want to encourage people to invest, what do we do—go around threatening people? Investment is a voluntary act by individuals or by companies, partnerships or various other business entities who make decisions based on their perceptions of the opportunities for making a profit from investments. After all, I remind the government that in the last several years most of the growth in business has been in very small business, which we expect will continue.

PARA.TAB: People who are looking to invest—and they are looking to invest—have a choice of whether they invest here or overseas. Basically, the government has been frightening those people and consequently encouraging them to invest overseas rather than here. Instead of trying to blame business for the lack of investment, the government should be looking in a mirror. After all, it was the government which accelerated interest rates here and led us into the recession we had to have. We had interest rates much higher than we needed and we had a recession which was longer and deeper than we needed.

Just as importantly, the industrial relations bill that went through the parliament in December was also an absolute positive deterrent to investment because it increased the uncertainty of the business world—of investors—about their people. With this bill, the government is signalling further ACTU involvement in the industrial relations scene and, again, the perception will be that the government does not want us to invest in Australia. Yet it is known by all advisers and commentators in the investment world that freeing up the labour market and not constraining it is the first priority for sustained economic growth in the long-term future.

I want to close now, Mr Acting Deputy President, by making sure the Senate understands that the threatening rhetoric we have been hearing from the government in recent months in an attempt to encourage investment has actually heightened concerns about investment and frightened people away from investing in Australia. I support the amendment moved by Senator Chapman.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the government—
—Thank the speakers and sit down so that we can get on with the business.

—That is the best invitation I have had all day. I was going to do just that. The opposition will not be surprised to hear that we are opposing the opposition's second reading amendment. I must make the point that the opposition has an absolute hide to mention industrial relations incompetence when the only previous track record for the delivery of conservative policies—where the rhetoric actually became the reality—was that of the Fraser government. I do not think that too many opposition members would actually argue against that; the facts speak for themselves. That period of government—I recall it only too well—was a period of runaway wage increases and an industrial relations disaster.

PARA.TAB: I do not think the government has anything to apologise for—quite the reverse—in terms of its industrial relations record. It is a very good one. So far as the `hasty' amendments are concerned, and I will conclude on this point, they are not hasty in that sense at all. They were brought forward because of particular requests that Justice O'Connor made. It is a mark of the extremely high regard in which we hold Justice O'Connor, and correctly so, in making this appointment that we have agreed to these—as I think one speaker opposite quite rightly put it—fairly minor amendments to the legislation. Having made those remarks, I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.
Amendment negatived.
