TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I have a general question. The explanatory memoranda appear to suggest that there are savings to be made by introducing the military compensation scheme. Could the minister specify how these savings are to be made?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am informed, the savings are administrative. The infrastructure for the administration scheme is already in place and will not require major enhancement to deal with an expected gradual increase in workload. It may be necessary to transfer some resources from the DVA to Defence as the number of beneficiaries under each scheme changes. There will be a decline in the overall workload of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. There is already a system in place in Defence for safety, rehabilitation and compensation and this system will result in administrative savings. Overall there will be minimal augmentation which will generally result in savings that are difficult to quantify precisely. Because of those administrative changes, we believe there will be an overall decline in costs.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I will come back to that when I am dealing with clause 11. I go to part 2 of the bill and ask: compared with access under the VEA to a specific treatment card and pharmaceutical benefits, what benefits will be available to the ADF member or veteran under the modified SRCA?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —All reasonable medical costs relating to the condition will be met.
—Will it be possible to hold one of the yellow, red, mauve or white treatment cards presently given to VEA beneficiaries?
—Senator, what you are asking for will not be met in those circumstances.
—I take it the patient will get whatever is required in the way of treatment from a medical provider?
—Yes, that is correct.
—What provisions will be made for transport for claimants under SRCA or the modified MCS scheme, as it exists at present, as compared with those who are entitled for treatment under the VEA?
—If it is as a consequence of a compensatable condition, then reasonable transport costs will be met.
—That means transport would not be available on all occasions then? Who would make the decision as to whether transport would be provided or withheld?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Generally, the doctor would be the person authorised to say whether transport is required. But the department determines what would then be a reasonable form of transport—whether it be a taxi, an ambulance or some other mode of transport—depending on the condition the doctor has identified and what he thinks is reasonable to transport the patient.

—What provisions are available under the MCS for dependants, particularly in relation to children's education? You would be aware, of course, that under the Veterans' Entitlements Act a TPI pensioner is entitled to some benefits with respect to children. Will there be any parallel provisions under the MCS?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —For clarification, is this after death?
—No.
—In all circumstances?
—Yes.

—There are two categories. For persons who are injured, but obviously not dead, there is no specific provision for education. There are weekly income-related payments in those circumstances. In the event of death there is a weekly benefit of $50.53 to each dependent child of the deceased member in addition to the lump sum payment.
—In what circumstances can a veteran apply for and receive both a lump sum under the military compensation scheme and a disability pension under the VEA?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand he or she can claim for both as a lump sum or an income, but the benefits of one are offset against the other. The total package may contain an element of both. In those circumstances, the claimant is also counselled and will have the option to choose between the two types of benefit.

—I understood that from the briefing I had from the advisers who are beside you. But, my question was, with respect, in what circumstances, not whether they can do it. Could you give me an example of a circumstance?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —A person can claim under either act if they have entitlement to claim and the circumstances in which this would occur are future operational service, hazardous service, peacekeeping, and those pre-VEA members who have peace time service.

—In relation to the offsetting provision that we have just talked about, at what stage will the offsetting of a lump sum given under SRCA be deemed to have been fully offset? Is it possible, for example, that the offset will go on for so long it will still be affecting a VEA disability pension after retirement? Therefore will some arrangement be made to ensure that it is repaid?
—The lump sum is offset against any other pension entitlement they may receive throughout the whole of their life.
—Is the parliamentary secretary saying that the lump sum payment is compensation for the estimated term of their natural life and that is why any other income support payments will cut out at age 65?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The lump sum is in recognition of either the extent of disability or death, in the event of death. The on-going income payment cuts out at 65 because that is the recognised age at which a person would cease to be earning an income if not incapacitated. It is the normally accepted age at which a person would retire. So the payments are recognising two different sets of factors.

—I will come back to that in a minute. I would now like to look at the journeying provisions under section 6 of the SRC Act. Do those provisions adequately cover ADF personnel for the extra days that they might be involved in travelling to exercises, or for accidents on days on which they are stood down from an exercise but are still away from their home or base camp? I would like Senator Sherry to expand on how the SRCA, which is essentially designed for the Public Service and is oriented with its benefits towards that, covers the different travelling times and requirements that members of the ADF are frequently involved in.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The MCS package provides effective compensation cover for members travelling in the course of ADF employment. The travel provisions of the SRC Act, upon which the MCS is based, are interpreted broadly by the Department of Defence which administers the act on behalf of members of the ADF. In administering the SRC Act, Defence understands the unique nature of defence service. We have looked at the option of amending the travel provisions of the act, and are convinced that to do so would only limit the ability of Defence to interpret those provisions to the advantage of members of the ADF.As Senator MacGibbon would know, the administration of the MCS is to remain with Defence under an interdepartmental agreement. Defence is assured of the ability to continue to administer the travel provisions in full understanding of the nature of the ADF service.

—I take it from that that Senator Sherry is saying that no member of the ADF will be penalised in any way at all by a narrow interpretation of what is time on duty when travelling. I understand that there have already been cases taken to the AAT by defence personnel because SRCA has proved not able to take the unique travelling situation of the ADF into account. I ask the parliamentary secretary for his view on those cases, and whether they should have been covered, and, in the light of that, does he still stand by the answer he has given me?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Without knowing the details of the cases to which Senator MacGibbon refers which are before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal—and it is not proper to give an opinion on those matters whilst they are before the tribunal in the context of this chamber—as I understand it, the dispute about the cases he may be referring to is related to whether or not ADF personnel were on duty rather than, although it would be a related issue, travelling to or from duty.

—Take the case of a reserve officer or a senior NCO who lives in a capital city and who has to travel maybe 200 miles to an Army Reserve unit outside the capital city. That is not an infrequent practice. There are officers who are required to leave at about three in the afternoon, do three or four hours driving, take a parade, do the paperwork and drive back after midnight. Is Senator Sherry telling me that when they are driving back at midnight the 200 miles to the capital city when the parade is over, that they are no longer on duty, therefore they are not covered?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very clearly in the example Senator MacGibbon has given us the travel is related to work, so the person would be covered in those circumstances.

—I am not an authority on that AAT case that I cited and I certainly do not want to canvass the outcome, but as I understand it there were some members of the ADF on an exercise, they were stood down for either 12 or 24 hours, they went on leave, and when they were walking back some of them were injured. Clearly they would not have been in the exercise area if they had not been on duty. To argue that they were on some sort of leave at the time seems to take a narrow view that I would find unacceptable. Since this legislation before us is based on the SRCA, and it is SRCA that is causing the problem, I have some concern.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The case that Senator MacGibbon refers to is before the AAT, and I cannot on behalf of the government give a general policy response to it because it would be prejudging it. However, the opinion of the AAT is important, and the department would take cognisance of the AAT's opinion on that particular case.

—Would Senator Sherry agree that it is a reasonable argument that those servicemen or servicewomen would not have been in that geographic location if they had not been on ADF duty? That, surely, is the fundamental point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one of the important salient factors but, as I understand it, the persons had been stood down and we would need to evaluate a range of factors, such as their activities after they had been stood down. It is not dissimilar from normal workers compensation cases where, certainly a person may be travelling to or from work, but one would need to take account of a range of criteria and activities that they are carrying out travelling to and from work.

PARA.TAB: So it is not a simple case of them being there because they were on exercise, full stop; it is a case of looking at the range of factors that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would have to evaluate. As I said earlier, it has not completed its evaluation. It is not possible for me to prejudge and give a firm opinion whilst we are waiting for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to look at the variety of factors involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we can take this matter much further at this time since it is still under appeal before the AAT, but I would state that it appears from Senator Sherry's answer he has clearly equated the ADF with industrial practice or with public service practice whereas we would certainly not see that comparison. I do not have an encyclopaedic knowledge of cases before the AAT. Can Senator Sherry tell me how many cases there are currently of a similar nature or which have been brought before the AAT in the last five years?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised there are approximately 80 cases, all up, before the AAT. The number relating to journey provisions is minuscule. I cannot give an exact number. I have asked the advisers to obtain a breakdown. As to the numbers over the last five years, again I cannot give a precise figure now. The department will obtain those figures and send them to Senator MacGibbon in as quick a time as we can reasonably respond.
—Moving to clause 3, what system will be available for reviewing a claim which is initially denied?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator MacGibbon is aware that at the moment there is an internal review for reconsideration provisions. That is carried out by an officer of the department who has no direct relationship with the case in any way. If the people are not satisfied with that, it is referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. If they are still not satisfied, it can go to the Federal Court on points of law. It is not envisaged that that existing system will change.

PARA.TAB: In response to concerns from the ex-service community, these reconsideration provisions have been examined. The government is confident that the provisions are fair and accessible. The reconsideration provisions do compare well with those applicable to the VEA and to other legislation. Many of the advocates consulted in the process of preparing this bill are satisfied with the way the reconsideration process works in practice. Defence will continue to examine the administration of the reconsideration process to ensure that it is fair.

At this stage it is not appropriate to establish a separate merit review authority, other than the AAT which presently applies. The Minister for Justice, my colleague Duncan Kerr, has asked the Administrative Review Council to examine issues relating to Commonwealth review tribunals including justification for review other than by the AAT. That review is likely to be concluded towards the end of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the greatest of respect, I do not think it is fair or accurate to say that the procedures under this bill compare well with what exists under the VEA because under the VEA there is an appeal to the Repatriation Commission, an appeal to the Veterans Review Board and then finally to the AAT; so there is a world of difference there. But if a claimant takes an appeal to the AAT, who will pay for that? Will he be recompensed for that as he would be if it was a claim under the VEA?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, on the point Senator MacGibbon raised, yes, I accept that there is a Veterans Review Board under the VEA. But in the consultations on this legislation generally—not in all cases—advocates were happy with the internal review process and preferred that approach to the Veterans Review Board approach.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, on the issue of costs, if a claimant is successful in having decisions varied by the AAT, the Commonwealth meets his or her costs. I also understand that, even if the claimant is unsuccessful, only rarely does the government press recovery of government costs in those circumstances. Thirdly, the AAT also has the authority to decide the costs. Given those circumstances, the claimant is generally in a very reasonable position when it comes to recovery of costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a different point of view from that of the advocates. I was told by the departmental briefing officers that there had been general acceptance of the proposition as outlined in the bill. All I can say is that I think I have talked to far more veterans organisations than the briefing officers and I have not found one who is happy with the proposition in this bill for an internal review process. As for the serving members of the ADF, I do not think any of them understand the bill—some would not even know of it—so I do not give much weight to their views. Could the minister outline specifically how this bill provides for better rehabilitation practices and retraining than are available under the VEA?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there is very little rehabilitation at the moment under the old VEA legislation, except in some limited cases for Vietnam veterans. But, under the new provisions of the MCS, much greater consideration is given to rehabilitation. Defence will integrate its administration of the scheme and ensure that it fulfils its responsibilities in the way that employers in other industries are increasingly doing in the rehabilitation area. It is generally no longer acceptable for employers, where they have been found to have injured an employee, not to take an interest in the rehabilitation of the injured individual.

PARA.TAB: A separate MCS, which is administered by Defence, brings that employer's responsibility into sharper focus. The responsibility for occupational health and safety, compensation and rehabilitation are all closely aligned. The MCS will allow Defence to integrate all of the aspects of this important area. Although the Department of Veterans' Affairs has a long history of administering veterans' benefits, it has had little experience in managing the type of rehabilitation and vocational retraining that is the hallmark of modern compensation legislation, such as the MCS. Defence is now fulfilling its rehabilitation and vocational training responsibilities under the SRCA and is well positioned to continue this for the MCS.

Much rehabilitation work is now carried out by the Defence Force's medical services and through a highly effective system of schools and training courses. The MCS allows the co-location of medical, occupational health and safety, compensation, rehabilitation and defence administration in the regional defence centres. This arrangement will help to ensure that an injured serviceman or servicewoman is provided with continuous support for a process of treatment and rehabilitation both within and without the service. It is important to keep the MCS separate from the VEA. Although both schemes provide excellent benefits, they are different schemes with a different focus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Setting aside rehabilitation for the moment and thinking about retraining, will there be any difference in the nature and the extent of retraining provided to an ADF member who stays in the ADF and a member of the ADF who is separated from the service because of injury?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —An ADF person who remains in the ADF continues as an employee. There is a range of courses within the ADF which a person could enter into and take part in. Clearly, a person who was in the ADF and who separates from the service would be in a different position as far as education and training are concerned. That person would be trained and/or assisted in a variety of education and training ways that would be relevant to what would be available in the normal marketplace outside the ADF. That training would have regard to the person's previous experience, training and education before going into the ADF and whilst in the ADF.

—Is there a financial limit on the retraining budget in any way at all or is the retraining directed to enhancing the trade or professional skills that a member of the ADF has so that person can transfer to civilian life? Will the government pay HECS fees, for example, for members of the ADF to enrol at a university or a TAFE?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that there is no budget limit for an individual. If it is believed that education at a university or a TAFE college is a relevant form of training and is the way for that individual to go then in those circumstances fees would be paid. There are not arbitrary figures provided for retraining or re-education costs, and I think that is to the advantage of the individual. There is a limit to which a person can retrain or re-educate, and that would have to be assessed. In those circumstances, after counselling, it may not be appropriate for a person to continue in that scheme or schemes in which he has been involved in. It is very hard to set an arbitrary limit whilst at the same time being fair in all the circumstances.

—Currently the VEA offers financial compensation for a disability as a consequence of service and that disability pension is paid through the natural life of the recipient. What comparable financial compensation would be offered to a member of the ADF in future who is covered only by the MCS and, after he separates from the service, he finds that he has increasing deafness as a consequence of having served in an artillery regiment for a while and is demonstrably suffering a disability? Will he be entitled to a disability pension in those circumstances?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two forms of compensation. Dealing firstly with the lump sum payment for disability: it is possible for a person who has received a lump sum in recognition of a disability to return at a later date. Having already received a payment following the initial assessment, if deterioration occurs that is determined—I would assume it is the medical practitioner who would determine this—to be greater than 10 per cent of the person's initial assessed impairment, there is the capacity to receive an additional lump sum in recognition of that continuing deterioration. A similar principle would apply with regard to income that is paid in recognition of the loss of income.

PARA.TAB: In relation to hearing, all the circumstances involving a continuing hearing loss have to be examined. I understand that, generally, human beings' sight and hearing deteriorates naturally over life. There may be other factors involved in alternative employment which lead to a deterioration in people's hearing or loss of sight—or whatever the particular deterioration is. So those factors would also have to be assessed in any revisiting of the disability and the initial payments made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the ageing argument for normal physical decline, but let us stick with the specific case of a gunner who serves for 10 or 12 years. He enlists at the age of 18 and retires from the army at around the age of 30 in good physical condition, having never made a claim under the MCS. At the age of 40, he goes along to his doctor because his wife is telling him that she is shouting at him and he is not listening. He finds that he has a 50 per cent impairment in his hearing.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that under the precedents of the VEA, a gunner would have no difficulty in showing that his deterioration in auditory acuity was greater than that for his age group and that his occupation as a gunner was the prime contributing factor. At that point, having been separated from the ADF for 10 or 12 years, can he make a claim under the MCS? If he can make a claim, what can he expect—both a lump sum and income support or just a lump sum?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I would like the minister at the table to give us some explanation as to why the appropiate minister is not handling this bill. It seems to me that Senator Sherry knows very little about it. We seem to be talking in two languages and wasting a lot of time. I would like an explanation as to why Senator Faulkner, who I believe normally handles this sort of bill, is not here.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—There is no point of order. However, it was a question directed to the minister and it is up to the minister whether he chooses to answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner explained to me that he had to go to Newcastle tonight and asked me whether I had any objection to any other minister taking this bill through. I have no objection.
—Thanks for that. If there was a private arrangement between Senator Faulkner and Senator MacGibbon I was not aware of it; so my question is still relevant.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the whips should have been informed, so I will rebuke Senator Faulkner when I see him next for handing this matter to me. I point out to Senator Panizza that this is not an unusual procedure.
—It would save a lot of time.

—I know it would save time, but we could defer the matter from the program and it would probably waste as much as time as we are wasting presently. To answer Senator MacGibbon's question, in general people would be evaluated in the same way under the MCS as they would under the VEA. Dealing with the specific matter of hearing, the national hearing centre would determine whether the hearing loss is related to noise exposure and, if so and if there are no other aggravating factors, a lump sum would be paid. If income loss has also eventuated, income support payments will also be paid up to the age of 65. So a person should not suffer any disadvantage either generally or specifically relating to the hearing loss matter that Senator MacGibbon raised under the MCS provisions.
—I advise honourable senators that Estimates Committee E is to meet during the dinner break, commencing immediately in committee room 2S1.

—Mr Chairman, I thought the government, having extended the sitting hours, would at least have a quorum present for the start at 8 o'clock, and I thought it might have a whip here at the same time. I am pointing out the state of the house. (Quorum formed)

—In the briefing papers that I received from the briefing team there is an entry concerning a lump sum for permanent impairment up to $101,080.90 and non-economic loss up to $37,905.34. Can I have a definition of what a `non-economic loss' is? I presume it is not part of the lump sum payment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The payment is part of the lump sum. The $101,000 is the general economic loss—functional impairment, those types of losses. The other sum is for loss of, say, social relationships, mobility, pain and suffering—those types of criteria.
—So the total payment in a lump sum form would be the sum of both those amounts?
—Yes, that is correct.
—Why is there a ceiling on the lump sum payments when that seems to be at variance with general compensation payments for injury in the community?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The lump sum payment is indexed, although there is a maximum. That was the maximum lump sum payment that was considered fair and reasonable by the parliament at the time. In addition to that lump sum payment, there is obviously the provision for loss of income in the form of a pension entitlement.

—I understand that. If the figure is indexed, can the parliamentary secretary tell me what it is at the present time? Is the figure of $138,986.24 the figure when SRCA was introduced in 1988 or is that the figure today?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —When SRCA was introduced the figure was approximately $120,000. The figure that the honourable senator has been referring to tonight is the figure at this point in time, following the indexation that has occurred.
—That figure was arrived at because somebody thought it was reasonable. Is that correct? What was the process?

—The sum referred to is that which was put in the original legislation. I was not here at that time, so I am not sure of the consultations which occurred—whether it was referred to committee or to what extent it was debated on that occasion. The figures that are set, whether in this area or in other jurisdictions, do vary from place to place. From my knowledge of workers compensation—I know this is not in the same form—the figures do vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.

—The Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act was passed in 1988, roughly six years ago. How many cases of maximum payout have occurred in the last six years during which the bill has been in existence?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have those figures available. We will endeavour to assist Senator MacGibbon by trying to obtain the figures in a reasonable time. I understand that there are some difficulties in obtaining the figures fairly quickly, but we will do our best for him.

—I would have thought that the parliamentary secretary's advisers would have those figures to hand, because it is a very relevant question. The government is asking us to approve a bill that provides for a lump sum payment. We have established what that lump sum payment is. By the standards of the time, with respect to all the circumstances under which a claim might be made, I would have thought that that sum was considerably inadequate. I would have thought the other thing the parliamentary secretary would have is a case history experience. The MCS is based on a bill which has been running for six years. It is important for the parliament to be able to judge whether the provision of a lump sum in the case of major injury is attainable for someone, if that person is badly injured.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have the figures. All I can add is that the figures are very low because the vast majority of cases do not reflect 100 per cent disability. The assessment of the extent of impairment is based on criteria used, as I understand it, by the American armed forces. If we consider the potential lump sum payment together with the possible pension entitlements and the increased emphasis in this legislation on ensuring rehabilitation of the servicewoman or serviceman involved through education, training and a range of other initiatives, I do not think that package is unreasonable.

—I am considering those other payments. This bill seeks to supplant the Veterans' Entitlements Act, which is the act covering members of the defence forces serving during peacetime. I do not think that to date Senator Sherry has shown that the benefits are equal to those that are presently enjoyed by members of the ADF. Let us put that aside. If Senator Sherry cannot tell me the number of payments that have been made for 100 per cent compensation under the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act, can he tell me what the average payment has been? He said that there has been a large number of lesser payments.
—No, I cannot tell Senator MacGibbon that figure.

—If we look at this on an actuarial basis—taking the figure of $101,080 plus the economic loss of $37,000—someone under the Veterans' Entitlements Act who receives a 100 per cent disability pension receives $433.80 per month, or $5,205.60 a year. Over 20 years, the payment is $104,112. What is the position of someone who qualifies for the equivalent of a 100 per cent disability pension at age 30? That person will presumably be in the work force, with the cut off at 65 years of age, for another 35 years. With the maximum ceiling Senator Sherry has outlined, that person will not come out of it as well as someone provided for under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that to make a valid comparison is dependent on the income that the individual receives. But under the VEA provisions one would receive a disability pension, the amount of which depends upon the proportion of one's disability. The medical and other related expenses are covered under the VEA in the same way as they are in the MCS, but under the latter a lump sum is received and, in addition to that, an income support payment to age 65. We would not accept Senator MacGibbon's contention that entitlements under the VEA are superior.

—Let us look at a real case—something which has happened within my personal experience. It is not fair to say that it is common but, tragically, it does happen. Take the case of a soldier in a truck going to an exercise in a training area. There is an accident and he is either killed or injured. Perhaps he becomes a paraplegic or quadriplegic. He is 22 years of age. Under the MCS he is on peacetime service. He will qualify for the lump sum payment. He will qualify for income support—presumably at the level of a private. What happens to that soldier when he reaches 65 years of age? At present he is covered under the VEA. He would be on a maximum rate TPI pension under the current VEA legislation which would not cut out at 65 years of age; it would see him through for the term of his natural life. What is the government doing for this soldier at 65 years of age? Is it putting him on the scrap heap? Has it got him out begging on social security? What happens to him?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that Senator MacGibbon's contention that the payment to that person cuts out at 65 years of age and that the person is then on the general community social security payment is incorrect. At 65 years of age, that person would be receiving a service person's superannuation entitlement, which is 76.5 per cent of that person's salary. Obviously the amount depends on the salary that person is receiving. But that amount would certainly be greater than the normal social security payments that are made when a person in the general community turns 65.

—I find that very confusing. Take the case of a 22-year-old soldier who ends up a quadriplegic or a paraplegic. He simply cannot continue to serve as a soldier—he cannot serve in any capacity in the Australian Defence Force. He must be invalided out. At age 22 he would have served, at most, four years. He would not qualify for his MSBS pension or a DFRDB which is now out of date. So this person really does not have any expectation of qualifying for his military superannuation payment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that Senator MacGibbon is incorrect. In the circumstances described, from the time of injury that individual would be entitled to a class A pension when he turns 65. (Quorum formed)
—What is a class A pension worth?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my previous answer, 76.5 per cent of salary from the date of discharge.
—Is any offsetting provision taken into account against the lump sum payment or is there any income support program along the way?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the lump sum that that person may receive is not offset against the superannuation payment or the other form of payment, the ongoing income payment.
—Surely it is the other way around, is it not?

—I will finish the answer and I will double-check. The income payment as a result of the incapacity does take into account the superannuation payment. But the person that Senator MacGibbon has based his example on would, as I understand, receive at least 100 per cent of what he was earning in the first 45 weeks that he was no longer working, depending on the circumstances and depending on the income level of the person described, which we do not know. That may come down, but to a figure that is no less than 70 per cent of what the person would have earned had he continued without an incapacity.

—Am I to understand then that this quadriplegic 22-year-old will receive a lump sum payment, he will receive 100 per cent income support for 45 weeks at what he was earning beforehand, he will then be discharged, he will have income support, and at age 65 he will go onto a class A pension at 76 per cent of what his salary was when he was serving?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that upon discharge the service person would receive the superannuation payment at class A. He would receive the income until age 65 that takes into account the fact that he has been discharged from disability. He may also receive a lump sum, depending on the extent of the disability. At the age of 65, the payment that has been made on an ongoing basis to take into account the disability will cease. The income support from the superannuation payment that he has received since he was discharged continues on beyond age 65. That payment is no less than 76.5 per cent of the salary that he would have earned during his working life.

—Let us look at another case: a veteran who served either on hazardous duties, operational duties or peacekeeping duties and therefore qualified under the projected legislation for an entitlement both under the military compensation scheme and the Veterans' Entitlements Act, has an injury, elects to be compensated under the military compensation scheme and leaves the service. Presuming all other qualifications are met, at age 60 can that veteran qualify for a service pension which he would be entitled to claim if he were covered by the VEA?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —He would only receive a pension for operational service, and the short answer to Senator MacGibbon's question is no.

—Why is the provision of the Veterans' Entitlements Act denied to someone who has served on operational, hazardous or peacekeeping duties? Is Senator Sherry talking about the present situation? I am talking about the future application of this new bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act the payment applies only for hazardous duty and police-keeping service. Under VEA, one receives a disability pension only where it is hazardous service or peacekeeping service. Under the VEA, one receives a disability pension and a service pension for operational service. That will not change under the new provisions.

—Let us look at another case where a disabled veteran, covered solely by the military compensation scheme, has a major disability and has received his lump sum compensation and income support. His wife clearly has a caring role. That role is recognised under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, particularly in the extreme disability case of the totally permanently incapacitated veteran, in various ways and benefits which the secretary knows very well. What is the comparable recognition for the role of that wife when the veteran is covered solely by the military compensation scheme?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the injured or disabled serviceman or woman requires personal care such as washing, medication or feeding, the provider of that service, in this case the wife—or spouse if the alternative situation occurs—can receive a payment of up to $252.70 per week.
—I suppose I did not make myself clear. I understood that from the act. But there is no residual benefit past age 65 for the wife or spouse in that circumstance.
—I am advised that the payment does continue past age 65.

—What happens if a veteran who has opted for coverage under the military compensation scheme is compensated for an injury and then, some years later, that injury recurs? Under the current legislation that service person can apply under the Veterans' Entitlements Act for some compensation. Will the same facility apply with the same ease of access under the military compensation scheme?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did answer this matter before dinner when Senator MacGibbon was referring to re-examination of entitlements due to changed circumstances under the previous provisions. The answer is yes, the service person has the same rights of access to be reassessed if their condition should deteriorate, based on the same criteria outlined earlier.

—Let us suppose that a veteran is in paid employment. He was compensated originally for this disability, which healed up, and then it recurred whilst he was in paid employment. How is the case determined with respect to compensation? Is the military compensation scheme void and the obligation then on the current employer, even though the original injury was related to his military service, or does it go back to the MCS?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of principle is common to workers compensation generally in other sectors of the community. If the injury recurs and the recurrence is solely related to the original injury with the original employer, it is the original employer that bears the responsibility. However, if the injury recurs and there is a part or whole contribution as a result of employment carried out with the new employer then the new employer is either partly or wholly responsible for payment.

—Let us look at the case of a widow of a former member of the ADF, who dies after age 65 of the effects of injuries received in peace time service, and that person has been compensated for this injury under the military compensation scheme. What benefits will the widow receive in that circumstance where, clearly, under VEA she should be entitled to some compensation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is a new claim she can elect to claim under either act as it suits her particular circumstances. She is able to claim under either MCS or VEA.
—If he had only peace time service, surely she would not be entitled to claim under the VEA?
—You are right, Senator MacGibbon; clearly if it is peace time service the claim would be made under MCS and not VEA.

—Does the Department of Defence intend to institute a full education campaign, because my experience of the ADF is that very few, if any, of the personnel understand what is in the act and the implications of it. If they are to be fairly treated, it seems to me there has to be a considerable education campaign delivered or administered so that they can make the informed choice between the MCS and the VEA.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree that there is not a total awareness of the provisions. The ADF has planned an education campaign to ensure that all serving members are made aware of their rights and responsibilities under the MCS. The ADF will initiate a long-term education strategy to improve the level of knowledge among service men and women about the compensation. This sort of change is not necessarily bad in the education context. Because the change is occurring—and I am not saying that this justifies the change—it does mean that there is a need to remind service men and women as to what their entitlements are under the new provisions. It is quite possibly a good thing that that education campaign will occur as a result of this change.

—It is said that a large number of cases are pending. Could Senator Sherry give me an estimate of the number of claims that the department anticipates in the next 12 months, the next three years and by the end of the decade?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that there are approximately 1,000 cases. Priority is given to those of urgent need. One of the underlying intentions of these provisions is that, with greater responsibility by the employer with respect to occupational health and safety issues and a variety of related issues, and with an increasing emphasis in the community, the claims over time would be reduced. But it is clearly not possible to give an accurate figure as to the number of cases in one year or five years or by the year 2000. It is just not possible to give an accurate figure in response to the question asked by Senator MacGibbon.
—I ask Senator Sherry to speak on behalf of the government as to its intentions with regard to the retention of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is not relevant to the legislation before us, but it is clear government policy that the department will continue.

—With the greatest respect, I think it is relevant. A major area of responsibility was removed from the Department of Veterans' Affairs by this government when it decided to get out of providing hospital care and either integrated within the state system or sold off the repatriation general hospitals. That takes a great deal of responsibility away from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. If we now move the responsibility for compensation and other entitlements away from the Department of Veterans' Affairs and transfer it, as will occur under this Military Compensation Act which will apply to all members of the ADF and certainly all peacetime members, these personnel will not have the right of a claim under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The government will then find that a great part of the responsibilities and duties of the Department of Veterans' Affairs will disappear. I am asking Senator Sherry quite directly: how long will this government keep the Department of Veterans' Affairs in existence?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can respond quite directly to Senator MacGibbon. That matter is not the issue here in terms of this legislation, and it is clearly government policy to maintain the veterans affairs department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the parliamentary secretary for his support. As he will have gathered from my questioning, I have a great concern about the position of veterans under this legislation when they reach 65 years of age. I think there is a considerable degree of ambiguity and some degree of uncertainty in the answers we have got. Those of us on this side of the chamber will be supporting the amendment of the government to include a serving member of the ADF on the SRCA committee. I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 10, page 4, at the end of proposed paragraph 89E(1)(fa) add the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: "(fb) a member nominated by an organisation or organisations representing veterans;".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be accepting the amendment. The bill already provides for Defence Force representation on the Safety Rehabilitation Commission. The commission supervises the administration of both the SRCA and the occupational health and safety legislation. An essential feature of the composition of the commission, after extensive consultations flowing from the Brown review of the Comcare program, was that it should represent employers, unions and government. An additional member to represent the veteran community would be inconsistent with this fundamental feature.

PARA.TAB: Also, if the government were to concede to the opposition's amendment, other organisations or lobby groups, such as superannuated public servants, who are not presently members of the commission, could also seek representation. With the introduction of an ADF representative, the commission will consist of 10 members. There has to be a reasonable limit to the size of the commission. A commission larger than 10 runs the risk of being unwieldy and inefficient.

The Defence Force member on the commission is charged with representing the interests of ADF members. It is important to note that members of the ADF are not represented by a registered trade union and, therefore, their interests are not represented by the ACTU on the SRC. A defence member on the SRC will give service personnel a voice in this important forum, which advises the government on occupational health and safety, rehabilitation and compensation matters as they relate to Australian government employees.

It will also ensure that the nature of defence service is fully understood by the commission. Membership of this commission will provide advantages to the ADF through exposure to the policy context in which occupational health and safety, rehabilitation and compensation mesh. Membership of the commission will enhance the ADF's awareness of the operational issues in the overall administration of the scheme.

In concluding my remarks, before we move to the vote on the amendment, I thank Senator MacGibbon for his tolerance in the circumstances of my dealing with this legislation, and for his interest, as reflected in the detailed and comprehensive questions that he has asked on this legislation.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator MacGibbon's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sherry) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSPECTOR-GENERAL OF INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Amendment Bill. It is very short; basically, it will facilitate the commission of inquiry that has been set up to inquire into ASIS. It will do so by ensuring that the inquiry has access to the information that is necessary to it. There being some doubt about that under the terms of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act, this amendment will ensure that such access can be provided. Therefore, we obviously support the spirit of what we find in this bill because we support the notion of the inquiry that the government has finally conceded to conduct.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, aspects of this inquiry still concern us. I wish to take a minute of the Senate's time to mention some of those concerns because while they remain outstanding we fear that they will prejudice the final determinations of the inquiry. That is something we obviously do not wish to occur. Concern has been expressed—in particular, by the shadow minister for foreign affairs, Mr Peacock, who has opposition responsibility in this area—about the appointment of Mr Michael Codd and Mr Chris Maxwell in their respective positions under this inquiry. We do not question their capability or integrity but we do question whether their appointment was appropriate in light of their previous relationships. I mention in particular Mr Codd's functions in the area of intelligence and security services—he presided over the secretary's committee on intelligence and security and the Office of Security Intelligence Coordination.

The concern, therefore, is that he is too close in his background. It would be better to have appointed someone to this task who can be seen publicly to be more at arms length from the issues that are being addressed by the commission. I stress that it is no criticism of Mr Codd's capacity or his integrity. If the findings of this commission are going to be accorded the sort of public support that we would like to see, it would have been more sensible for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to have kept the commission more at arms length from what it is charged to examine.

Mr Maxwell concerns us because he was so close to Senator Evans; he worked in his office when Senator Evans was Attorney-General. It is bad judgment by Senator Evans. We regret that it has occurred. We have invited him to address it, but he has declined to do so. I guess that is not surprising, because that is the way that Senator Evans normally approaches these matters. But it will be seen to be a shortcoming of the process that is the subject matter of this debate.

We have criticised—and I do again—the terms of reference of the inquiry, which seem to us to be too vague and narrow. The functional role and priorities of ASIS have been excluded. The inquiry is really only looking into how ASIS was run and not what it did.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I remind you that the night before Senator Evans announced this inquiry he was assuring us that what he had in mind was a `root and branch inquiry' into ASIS. He told us that one of the motivating factors was that the Cold War was over and that we must re-examine ASIS in light of the new strategic environment. That can only be interpreted in one way: there is a need to examine the functions and priorities of ASIS in the new strategic environment. Yet by the following day he told us that that was unnecessary and that he did not intend to give the inquiry the breadth to examine such a fundamental question. We believe that that is a major shortcoming of this inquiry.

We certainly do not accept the justification that Senator Evans gave for the revision of his thinking, which is that an internal inquiry had already taken place within the last few years. From memory, I think it occurred in 1992. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will remember, from the little you would have seen about it in the press, that it was purely an internal review.

We believe that it is necessary to now look beyond the views of the Canberra bureaucracy. Therefore, what logically follows is that the minister has given us no justifiable explanation for his overnight change of mind. One can only assume that pressure was put on him from some direction; one knows not what. The legacy will be that this inquiry will take place and will be concluded without there being any outside examination of the objects and priorities of ASIS in this new strategic environment. That is a disappointing shortcoming. An opportunity has been lost by this government, and no satisfactory explanation has been given for it.

We are concerned that some of the allegations that were made were operational allegations. It is hard to imagine how they can be examined without looking at the functional role and priorities of the body itself. We are also concerned about the threats that appeared in Senator Evans's press statement in relation to the ASIS officers whose public concern has led to this inquiry—a public concern that they voiced under very difficult circumstances.

The government cannot have it both ways. On the one hand, the government cannot criticise them for voicing their concerns about an important, secret and, therefore, protected body within our bureaucracy and, on the other hand, acknowledge that there is sufficient justification arising out of their concerns to set up a commission of inquiry of this nature. If Senator Evans accepts that there is sufficient justification to set it up, then we believe that to finish his press release with threats to the individuals concerned is unsound, unhelpful and does not demonstrate from the minister the sort of good faith that we have a right to expect.

We have to remember that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security validated at least some of the expressions of concern of these officers who made complaints when he found, in relation to issues concerning their labour relations, that they had been handled `improperly'—I think that was the word he used in one of his annual reports. Certainly, he said that they had been denied natural justice. In those circumstances where the Inspector-General gives credit to aspects of their complaint, their personal grievances, one wonders whether there might be some validity to the claims that they make on operational matters.

I guess that is one of our fundamental concerns that we are pleased has resulted in an inquiry of this type. The fact that they have received some support from the Inspector-General into certain aspects of their complaints at least gives them sufficient basis to justify an inquiry into those which are much more difficult to explore: the operational questions. It also indicates that the people making complaints deserve to be treated with more respect in their expressions of concern than what they have received from Senator Evans to date.

How these particular former ASIS officers are supported in this inquiry will, again, demonstrate how serious the government is in fairly addressing their concerns. The question of legal assistance is one that is still on the table. I will be interested to hear what support the government is prepared to give them to ensure that their case is put to this inquiry in a proper and professional way; certainly in a way that is at least as professional as that which is going to be put by others denying their claims.

It is critical now that the government has gone down this path that it gets to the bottom of these very serious allegations so the public can be reassured in the future that ASIS conducts its business in a way that the public has a right to expect. I understand that the inquiry will look at the operation of ASIS within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and into the well-known public antagonism against ASIS that exists within parts of the foreign affairs bureaucracy. Without a sound working relationship between the two bodies under the same umbrella, the public obviously will suffer a loss of confidence and there will be a loss of efficiency. If, as I understand it, the inquiry is going to look at that issue, we will be pleased to see it.

In summary, the case obviously was made out for an inquiry. We are pleased that it is occurring. We are very sceptical about Senator Evans's explanation that he had been giving this inquiry consideration for some time, firstly because he told us the same day as he said he was considering it that there was no need. Between question time during the day and estimates in the evening he apparently changed his mind. Secondly, he said that he had been considering it for some time and it needed to be root and branch, thus obviously raising the issue of objects and priorities. Yet the following day he decided that that was not necessary.

Such confusion does not give us confidence that it had been well thought through by Senator Evans, but rather that he had been induced to go down this path by public embarrassment caused by the revelations made public by these officers. While not having great confidence in his planning for this process, we are nevertheless pleased that it is occurring. We wish only to record that we would have been happier if he had ensured that in the structure of both the commission and its counsel those with vested interests were to be kept more at arms length. We would also have been happier if he had gone as far as he indicated that he desired to go—and had a full inquiry, including an inquiry into the functions and objects.

Honourable senators on my side of the chamber have been supportive of ASIS over the years. But when bodies are protected by secrecy, as this one needs to be, it places upon the government perhaps a greater responsibility than in relation to other parts of the bureaucracy to ensure that the body keeps to its charge and its objects, to ensure that it is efficiently managed to achieve those objects and, particularly, to ensure that staff who have less recourse to public avenues of support than staff in other areas are properly treated and do not get into difficulties with ASIS, eventually being told by an adjudicator that they were denied the principles of natural justice.

In all those circumstances, as I said, from time to time when there is public questioning of these objects, functions, priorities and methods of doing business it is necessary for a proper outside examination. Tonight we are half pleased; pleased that the job is being done, but regretful that it is only being half done. But in relation to this specific bill and the capacity of the commission therefore to get the material it needs from the Inspector-General, we obviously support it.(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have heard, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Amendment Bill 1994 relates to the impending commission of inquiry into the operation and management of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, ASIS. These amendments will enable the Inspector-General of ASIS and his staff, both current and former, to appear before the commission of inquiry and to give evidence, including documentation, something not currently permitted within the provisions of the act.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats agree that the commission of inquiry must have unimpeded access to all the necessary and relevant documentation as well as information from officers of ASIS without the risk of prosecution of those giving evidence at this inquiry. Under the circumstances, the Democrats are pleased to support these amendments as they will undoubtedly strengthen the inquiry's scope and enable the commission to examine ASIS operations in accordance with the government's terms of reference. As to those terms of reference, the Australian Democrats have a number of concerns which we have previously stated in relation to ASIS operations and about which we hope the commission of inquiry will deliver some positive recommendations.

There should by now be no doubt that ASIS is, in all probability, an organisation operating out of control. The government's desire to have the commission of inquiry examine the current arrangements for the control and accountability of ASIS indicates that the government also has concerns. The recent ABC Four Corners program on ASIS revealed remarkably disturbing aspects of the operations of this country's foreign intelligence services. We believe a great many people who saw that program were as alarmed as we were at the allegations contained in the program and, in particular, at claims that Australia was involved in illegal activities in other countries.

It is worth repeating here that we believe the whole question of why Australia is involved in the foreign intelligence business at all should come within the scope of this commission of inquiry. The Democrats do not accept that a middle-sized power such as Australia has any real reason to be involved in foreign intelligence, and we sincerely doubt that there is any lasting benefit to this country by indulging in this sort of activity. For instance, why on earth is ASIS involving itself in intelligence operations being conducted by both the British and the US in third countries? How do these sorts of operations bring any benefit to our foreign policy?

The Democrats are concerned that the allegations surrounding ASIS will do substantial damage to Australia's reputation in the international community. Clearly, ASIS is an organisation which at the moment is accountable to no-one. The effectiveness and the value of Australia's foreign intelligence services are severely in question here.

Against this background, the issue of oversight of ASIS is perhaps the most important aspect of the examination to be conducted by the commission of inquiry, and the terms of inquiry reflect this. As I said at the time this issue arose, it is an essential cornerstone of democracy that no body or group can be or should be above the law. There is absolutely no justification whatsoever for any government instrumentality to effectively operate as a law unto itself, as ASIS now appears to be doing. We obviously cannot allow this to continue.

If ASIS is to continue then there must be serious thought given to control and accountability mechanisms now in place. Accordingly, the Democrats note and welcome the commission of inquiry terms of reference, which will include an examination of current control and accountability processes. We believe there needs to be better oversight of ASIS and its operations.

Some time ago I asked the minister a series of questions about the accountability of ASIS and how similar foreign intelligence services, such as MI6 or the CIA, were monitored in the United Kingdom and in the United States. It is worth repeating that in those countries a process is in place whereby both intelligence agencies are scrutinised by their respective legislatures. In the UK, for instance, parliamentary oversight is now being put in place which will hold to account both the internal and the external intelligence agencies of that country. Perhaps we need to look at setting up a similar structure here. One option may be to expand the role and responsibility of the parliamentary committee currently overseeing the operations of ASIO so as to bring in ASIS as well. We will be awaiting with very keen interest the outcome of the commission's recommendations on this subject.

On another matter, the Democrats express some reservations that the commission's terms of reference are not sufficient to examine the grievance system now in place in ASIS. Quite clearly—the Four Corners report underlined this point—the existing grievance system for staff appears to have failed. Serious allegations have been made and the Democrats are concerned at this stage that the commission of inquiry should be in a position to deliver some form of justice to those officers and ex-officers who have legitimate grievances against ASIS. In all of this, the Democrats believe it is important that former officers of ASIS not be forgotten. In spite of all this, and in many ways because of all this, the Democrats support the bill.
