SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is finally dealing with the last of four omnibus tax bills or amendment law bills which were introduced into the parliament during 1993. I remind the Senate that there are in excess of 20 taxation proposals previously announced which the government has yet to legislate.

PARA.TAB: Before the Senate rises prior to the budget session the parliament will have before it another omnibus tax bill correcting further difficulties. This bill seeks to amend the already complex Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 and the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.

Because time will not allow me to dwell on all the relative merits and drawbacks of each measure, I will be fairly selective in my remarks. I deal firstly with the fringe benefits tax. The general exemption to employees for travel in foreign locations rectifies a problem that should never have existed or been created in the first place. The change in the fringe benefits tax is that the rate applicable to many non-profit organisations will extend to non-government schools under Commonwealth, state or territory legislation.

The amendment rectifies a deficiency in the original legislation which the explanatory memorandum says was unintentional. Luckily for those potential casualties of the government's attempt to legislate, this deficiency has now been picked up and the amendment is supported by the National Council of Independent Schools Associations and will extend the grossing up rebate to a number of schools in Tasmania, including the Hutchins School, St Michaels Collegiate School, the Launceston Church Grammar School and Scotch Oakburn College.

The final FBT change is aimed, I guess, to increase tax revenue by eliminating the loophole that employers had found with the FBT on car parking provisions. I draw the Senate's attention to how quickly the government often moves to rectify measures if there is an intended loss to revenue. Presently, employers must pay FBT on car parking benefits, mind you, provided to their employees. Naturally, some astute employers have minimised the FBT payable by selecting low reference rates—the fees charged at kerbside meters or the night-time fees set by commercial parking stations. The effect of this amendment is that fringe benefits tax will be calculated in relation to daytime rates from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. only, and that parking meters will not be considered `commercial parking stations'. I remind the Senate that, in effect, each car parking space may attract a double tax, especially where more than one car uses that space in any particular day. I also remind the Senate of the very high compliance costs associated with identifying cars coming in and going out of car parking spaces.

In that light, I confidently predict that this amendment will not clarify the matter sufficiently. I forecast that problems will arise with the concept of `commercial parking rate' which could vary between locations. One way of eliminating this problem altogether would be to use a standard rate applicable to all employers, irrespective of location. If the Australian Taxation Office adopted a commonsense approach to interpreting the legislation as it currently stands, this amendment would not be necessary. However, instead, there have already been determinations as to the measurement of the one-kilometre radius, the form of valuation required, what is a commercial parking station, the valuation of car parking benefits and the valuation of benefits for a particular day—just to name a few.

In relation to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, we find nine amendments for measures which will add something like 40 pages or more to already complex legislation. Taking this in the light of announcements made by the government over the past few years about simplification—15 February 1990, November 1992, 1 September 1993 and 17 December 1993—I am a little perplexed as to what the government's real intention is because quite often the complexity of taxation laws is increased.

The amendment on the question of luxury cars will force those lessors of luxury cars who use the finance method of returning their assessable income to take account of the depreciation limits, thereby increasing their assessable income. The government estimates that approximately $60 million is at risk if this measure is not implemented.

I remind honourable senators of litigation involving Citibank on the issue of leasing arrangements. The finance method in that case was rejected and the taxpayer was refused special leave to appeal to the High Court on the decision of the Full Federal Court where that court held that Citibank was assessable on the gross rentals received under the finance leases of cars but was entitled to depreciation allowances, subject to section 57AF cost limits.

The amendment in clause 51 aims to ensure that liability for franking additional tax is not affected where franking deficit tax can be offset by an initial payment of company tax. The proposed amendment will apply to overfranking of a dividend that is paid after 14 December 1993 when this bill was introduced into the House. In relation to overfranking of tax—I must say that I will not comment on an aspect in the original bill—I am pleased that the government does intend to raise an amendment to correct a problem in relation to dividends declared and paid that could have resulted in some unintentional tax paid by companies because of approximately a nine-day difference between the dates dividends have to be declared and actually paid.

The Taxation Institute of Australia argues that, with changes to the corporate tax payment system whereby companies will pay 85 per cent of their prior year tax liability within 28 days of the end of the year, there should be no real concern in allowing companies to include the 85 per cent tax payment in their calculation of franking credits for the prior year.

I turn to the heritage conservation rebate. This amendment will give a 20 per cent rebate for approved expenditure of at least $10,000 on conservation work on heritage listed buildings. Heritage conservation work is defined as work for the conservation, maintenance, preservation, restoration, reconstruction or adaptation of a building or other structure of cultural significance and is listed on a heritage register declared by the responsible minister as a recognised heritage register.

This is a bureaucratic, essentially two-step process to be administered by the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services. I note that there is a $2 million cap per annum so it appears that, unless the government wishes to clarify my assumption, the rebate will be available on a first come, first served basis. The Taxation Institute of Australia and others have concerns about the rebate scheme. The institute states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the inclusion of a further Division, to provide a rebate, albeit for a commendable purpose merely adds further to the complexity of the Assessment Act.

I agree with the institute's suggestion that a better alternative is a grant system administered by DAAS, which is responsible for issuing certificates on which the rebate system is based anyway. I certainly hope that, when we come to power and attempt to simplify the Income Tax Assessment Act, the rebate system will be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate grants system administered by the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services or another appropriate authority.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty is that the institute rightly emphasises that expenditure may be totally unconnected to any income earning activity of the taxpayer and argues that there is no policy for including the rebate within the tax system as it merely adds to its complexity. We have received representations from the Australian Council of National Trusts which are not all that complimentary to the rebate scheme. It, too, states that the rebate `represents a most important initiative for heritage conservation in Australia'. But the praise stops there and the criticisms commence. The council indicates that it and other heritage organisations have lobbied for a considerable time for the introduction of the scheme which was first mooted in Australia by the Hope inquiry in the early 1970s.

The council's major concern is that buildings or structures must be listed on Commonwealth, state or territory registers. There are particular problems in Tasmania; but I understand from Mr Cleary that the council is seeking to rectify those issues very quickly. In relation to that, during the committee stage I will be moving a couple of amendments—one to deal with a reduction from $10,000 in minimum expenditure to $5,000 and another in relation to the extension of the classified registers.

There is the problem of the $2 million annual cap. Anyone would realise that capping curtails the full potential of a scheme and has a number of problems. Perhaps $2 million is a minuscule amount, albeit a step in the right direction. A more appropriate figure, I have been told with certainty, is of the order of $20 million.

There are a number of problems with this rebate scheme. Any expenditure incurred on work before a provisional certificate is issued will not be rebatable. Expenditure on the acquisition of depreciable plant and articles is not rebatable. No rebate is available if expenditure does not exceed the qualifying expenditure limit. For that reason we will be moving to bring the limit down from $10,000 to $5,000.

I now move to the issue of pensions and annuities. The amendment extends the rebate currently enjoyed by superannuation pensions and roll-over annuities paid from a taxed source to superannuation pensions and roll-over annuities bought by rolling over an ETP representing the commutation of a deferred annuity or a pension from an untaxed superannuation fund. I note that it has taken the government only since 1988 to rectify this matter since once again the existing legislation unintentionally excluded immediate annuities.

I now move to the issue of company instalments. The amendment lays down the grouping rules for company tax instalment arrangements and has the effect that all companies forming a group with a likely tax bill of greater than $300,000 per year and whose likely individual tax is over $8,000 must pay tax instalments according to the rules for `large' taxpayers. This makes a significant change to when tax is payable. A `small' taxpayer pays tax in one instalment 18 months after the start of the financial year, whilst large taxpayers pay in four instalments with the first due nine months after the start of the financial year, being 25 per cent of the estimated liability payable for the first three months.

Large companies will be required to lodge their tax returns on 1 December instead of 15 March. The issue at stake is how much or how far the government can squash the cash flow lemon of companies in Australia without impeding their competitiveness, profitability and available cash resources. This will be felt most by corporations with high manufacturing content—those with long lead times between the taking of raw materials and conversion into a manufactured state—or even miners.

As a consequence of this amendment, there is a substantial contraction of the time interval and a bunching effect during which returns must be prepared. The taxation environment in which companies operate today is constrictive. They must cope with initial tax, quarterly instalments and then extra taxes arising from changes to fringe benefits tax. This is due to the fact that previously certain expenses were not subject to FBT; they are now deductible but subject to FBT. This tax must also be paid during the year in which the benefit is paid to an employee. The whole tax scenario leads to a contraction in cash flow and additional payments by corporations in a contracted time interval.

In addition, the penalty provision for new company tax instalment arrangements is amended to ensure that the penalty for underestimation of tax cannot be avoided by lodging two estimates in quick succession. I note that the group test applied for company instalment tax arrangements differs from that applicable in other taxation areas and I query why different tax approaches are used in different areas. For example, the group test for the transfer of tax losses is 100 per cent common ownership.

In passing, I note that the extension of the eligibility of the tax concession on infrastructure borrowings to construct infrastructure facilities on land leased from the Commonwealth and to pay interest on direct infrastructure is clearly a step in the right direction. But I wonder whether the government has given sufficient consideration to the scope of some provisions if its objective is to truly encourage private sector involvement in infrastructure.

Quite a few amendments are being made to the superannuation guarantee charge. They include making it clear that statutory authorities whose enabling legislation otherwise exempts them from Commonwealth taxation are liable for the superannuation guarantee charge; excluding lump sum payments for accrued leave, long service leave and sick leave on termination from the calculation of employer contributions; extending the superannuation guarantee charge to contractors; and deferring the quarterly superannuation guarantee charge obligations until 1994-95.

Let us be quite frank: none of these amendments address the real problems the superannuation guarantee charge scheme is riddled with. The government seems to ignore the many casual, part-time and itinerant workers whose superannuation benefits are eroded by taxes, fees and charges. I am pleased that the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation will be examining this very matter through the taking of submissions and public hearings later this year and that it will be reporting to the Senate. Someone has clearly got to look at this massive problem. The government's promises in August of last year to give high priority to resolving the problems has unfortunately fallen by the wayside or its timetable has slipped. I am glad that all these people do not have to wait to see how long this government defines as high priority.

The coalition is extremely concerned that the government is widening the `employee' net so that contractors will also be caught. Would it not be far better to eradicate the patently clear problems first and then bring others within the ambit of an effective superannuation scheme? Contractors' livelihoods will be adversely affected by this amendment. Accordingly, I call on the government to exempt contractors from the provisions of the superannuation guarantee legislation.

I wind up by saying that the government placed at the last minute a series of amendments covering something like 16 pages of new taxation law affecting life assurance registered organisations. The intent is to limit the deductibility of expense in a range of scenarios. I have been assured that the amendments have been made following consultations with the respective industry parties involved. Since I have received no representation, I believe that there would be an acceptance of those most recent amendments. Accordingly, I move:
At end of motion, add: ", but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)condemns the Government for:
(i)its lack of concern for the many casual, part-time and itinerant workers whose superannuation benefits are eroded by taxes, fees and charges; and
(ii)extending the coverage of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge to contractors;
(b)calls on the Government to:
(i)modify the Superannuation Guarantee Charge system immediately so that it treats casual, part-time and itinerant workers fairly; and
(ii)exempt contractors from the provisions of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge legislation".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is a series of specific proposals for changes in the taxation arrangements and regimes. My colleague Senator Watson dealt with many of the specifics of the bill in some detail, and he will be pursuing those aspects in the committee stage. I do not propose tonight to revisit that ground. I wish to talk more broadly about the government's taxation policy and the forthcoming budget. But first I want to raise what I consider to be a major concern about the government's handling of this bill, especially the amendments and requests to be moved to the bill by the government.

PARA.TAB: This bill is classified as one which does not impose taxation. I should say at the outset that I appreciate the advice that has come to me and to other members on both sides of the chamber from the office of the Clerk of the Senate. Many of the government amendments to the bill, however, despite the fact that it is classified as a bill that does not impose taxation, are to be moved in the form of requests for amendments because the view is taken that they will increase the liability to taxation and therefore fall within the third paragraph of section 53 of the constitution insofar as they would `increase any proposed charge or burden on the people'.

It seems to me that a very important paradox is quite apparent here. How can an amendment increase a proposed charge or burden on the people when the bill to be amended is classified as a bill which does not impose taxation and, therefore, presumably, does not propose any charge or burden on the people? How can a bill which could be introduced in the Senate because it is not a bill imposing taxation then be amended in such a way as to increase the burden of taxation? Can the Senate introduce a bill which it cannot itself amend in that way? If the proposed amendments have to be requests because they would increase a charge or burden on the people, then does it not follow that the provisions in the amendments actually impose taxation?
These are fundamental questions that I believe the government needs to answer in the context of this bill. I am not sure whether Senator Schacht is handling the bill for the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook will be later.

—I hope he will pass these questions on to Senator Cook. We expect answers to them before we get to the nitty-gritty of the details of the bill. It really goes to the whole core of the role of the parliament, and particularly the role of the Senate, in relation to taxation measures.
—You can't have it both ways.

—As my friend Senator Watson says, you cannot have it both ways. The government cannot say, on the one hand, that it is not a bill to increase taxation and then have amendments which increase taxation. It must choose either one course of action or the other, not both. It appears that this is what the government is doing with this bill.

PARA.TAB: If the whole thing is reduced to a reductio ad absurdum as a result of the classification of these bills, I think it runs a real risk that, in due course, when the High Court comes to a judgment on the meaning of laws imposing taxation, we, through our actions here—or, more specifically, the government through its actions in terms of the classification of bills—will be seen to have been very destructive in terms of the end result that may well be achieved. I raise that at the outset of my remarks because I consider it to be a very important aspect indeed.

Let us now look at the government's taxation policy and its approach to the forthcoming budget. We should never forget that last year's post-election budget was unequivocally a budget of deceit and betrayal. We got election promises, hype in the government's proposals and promises, and glad words before the election about no increases in taxation. We had the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) saying just three months before the election, `What I am promising is not to put up tax. I do not think the incidence of tax should rise', and the then finance minister, now Treasurer (Mr Willis), just after the 1993 election saying that the government `does not intend to increase the overall burden of taxation'.

Despite these statements we have had, as a result of the re-election of the Keating government a year ago, across-the-board rises in wholesale sales tax of up to 20 per cent and a massive 30 per cent hike in petrol excise—7c a litre. There has been a major reneging on the government's so-called One Nation income tax cuts which were to be worth something like $8.5 billion. Only $3 billion worth of tax cuts was delivered and the remaining $5.5 billion worth was pushed off to never-never land, which means that they will never be introduced. Of course, the government never intended that these cuts would be introduced because the government never thought it would be in a position where it had to honour that promise as it did not think it was going to win the election.

We are in a post-1993 budget and pre-1994 budget context where we have an electorate, a taxpaying community, which has seen all those promises shattered. In the current financial year, 1993-94, the taxation revenue was budgeted to equal 21.9 per cent of the gross domestic product. This year, on the estimates provided at the time of the last budget, and since revised, it rises to a whopping 22.8 per cent. On the government's own figures, that is an increase next year in real terms of 8.1 per cent. By 1996-97 it will, again on the government's own figures, have risen further to a figure of 23.5 per cent of gross domestic product. In other words, taxation revenue by 1996-97 will be not far short of one-quarter of total GDP.

We have the situation where income tax, sales tax and petrol tax are higher and the fringe benefits tax burden is greater. It looks almost certain that we will have another hike in the Medicare levy this year—whether it rises from 1.25 per cent to the 2 per cent that the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) obviously wants or whether it is some figure in between, we will have to wait and see. What is quite certain is that there will be an increase in the Medicare levy. We look like having the prospect of another new tax in the form of a so-called jobs levy. Different words have been said about that, but it has not been ruled out yet.

We are facing changes to the tax treatment of superannuation, which seems quite certain to result in another tax hike. So, we are, and have been for 12 months now, in an environment of high and rising taxes with no prospect of that turning around. Indeed, on the government's own expectations and forecasts publicly produced, far from any tax burden falling, the overall burden is forecast to increase.

That brings me to this year's budget, which is now only six or seven weeks down the track. The Treasurer has announced in his fiscal framework that the government believes there is a starting point deficit for 1994-95 of around $13 billion. That compares with what is expected to be an outturn for this year of something of the order of $14.75 billion—a far too high and unacceptable budget outturn. TALK.START.PARA: asked the then Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are chemical companies using Landcare to advertise and promote their products.
(2) Is Landcare supporting the use of chemicals.
(3) Will there be any harmful side effects in the future resulting from the widespread use of chemicals by Landcare groups.
(4) Will Government and therefore taxpayers be liable for substantial compensation as happened with dieldrin.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) As part of their promotional activities some chemical companies do sponsor landcare activities at the local, state and national levels. For example, Monsanto Australia is a sponsor of the Roundup Primary Producer Category in the National Landcare Australia Awards. The National Landcare Awards are organised by Landcare Australia Limited (LAL), a company established to encourage awareness and sponsorship of landcare. Acceptance of sponsorships by LAL should not be seen as endorsement of the sponsors' products, but rather as endorsement of landcare by the sponsoring companies.

(2) The safe use of chemicals is consistent with achieving certain Landcare objectives. The use of sprays to control blackberries is one example. The use of weed killing sprays as part of minimum tillage cropping practices leading to reduced soil erosion and associated water pollution is another.

In seeking to establish sustainable land use systems the National Landcare Program does not advocate any particular method of managing land, water and vegetation. The most appropriate management regime is a matter which the individual resource managers must decide, taking account of the best available information from all sources. It goes without saying that appropriate regimes need to take account of government regulations concerning natural resource use and chemical use.

(3) In 1993 the Commonwealth established the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals. Pesticides are thoroughly evaluated for safety to the environment and the user before they are registered. Possible side effects are taken into account in such evaluations. Chemical manufacturers are required to provide detailed information to substantiate any claims made in respect of their products. Only those chemicals which meet the established criteria are permitted to be released.
(4) In the light of the arrangements outlined in answer to question (3), a situation analogous to the dieldrin situation should not arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 21 December 1993:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by Telecom:

PARA.TAB: (1) This information is regarded as commercial-in-confidence by Telecom.
(2) Bell Canada International's (BCI) terms of reference were:

as technical experts, assess the inherent ability of Telecom's network to complete calls, advise on the actions taken by Telecom to resolve the network service difficulties reported by particular customers, and examine the background and network configuration relating to two or three of these customers as case studies; and

advise on the adequacy of other tests conducted to ensure that service provided meets the normal standards of service provided to customers generally in a global sense

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 24 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What criteria are used in the selection of the consumer representative to the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee.
(2) With reference to these criteria, on what basis were the previous two consumer representatives and the current consumer representative appointed to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The appointment of a member to the Plant Variety Rights Advisory Committee to represent consumers is made under paragraph 45(1)(d) of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 ("the Act"). The term "consumer" is not defined in the Act, but following advice received from the Attorney-General's Department in 1991, the term "consumer" was broadly interpreted to mean either any member of the public or a consumer of new varieties or a consumer that uses products derived from new varieties as raw materials. The selection criteria to be fulfilled by the consumer representative are that the person so nominated must have, in the opinion of the selection committee which advises the Minister, appropriate experience and qualifications to adequately fulfil the function of representative of one or more categories of consumer. Weight in the selection process is also given to the representational breadth of the nominee.

(2) The first consumer representative was a solicitor with experience in public and administrative law nominated by the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations. The second representative was an agricultural economist with qualifications and research experience in the nature and socio-economic impact of plant variety rights. The nomination of the third and current representative was supported by the Council of Australian Food Technology Associations. This person has qualifications and research and development experience in developing consumer products from new varieties of agricultural crops. In its formative stages the Australian Plant Variety Rights Scheme and the legislation on which it is based has gained appreciably from the cumulative advice received from the breadth of experience of the consumer representatives that have represented a wide spectrum of relevant consumer interests in plant variety rights.

The Facilities Upgrade program is a multi-year program of works under which the Commonwealth's network of transmission facilities is being upgraded to accommodate the Television Equalisation Program, expansion of VHF-FM radio transmission facilities for ABC radio services and, in some areas, the clearance of television transmissions from Band II frequencies.

The Gore Hill project involves the provision of enhanced transmission facilities to broadcast ABC-TV, SBS-TV, ABC Fine Music, ABC-JJJ and SBS

ANSWER.PARA: Radio to the residents of Sydney. It is a multi-year project which initially proposed the construction of a new, taller and higher capacity tower on the existing site at Gore Hill.

PARA.TAB: After initial design and environmental planning studies were completed for the proposed tower in 1990, estimated costs were clearly prohibitive. An alternative approach was developed, based on refurbishment and limited development of the existing tower at Gore Hill, and the relocation of UHF transmission facilities for SBS-TV to the Channel 7-10 commercial tower at Artarmon.

Refurbishment of the Gore Hill tower is in progress and due for completion in July 1994. Negotiations with the Commercial owners of the Artarmon facility have been complicated and protracted, due in large part to changes in the ownership of these companies. Expenditure on the Artarmon component of this project has been limited to design and feasibility studies on tower strengthening, antenna and building requirements.
Deferment of $6,835,000 is proposed because of the lack of progress with the Artarmon elements of this project, and the need for further review of the available options.

(2) There are no written guidelines which determine priorities between programs of extension of signal coverage. The Government determines its strategic priorities by establishing programs for extending or improving the signal coverage of particular ABC and SBS radio and television services, usually in the context of a Budget; within such programs, the Minister is responsible for establishing priorities for particular projects, taking into account such factors as the population to be served; and any technical or site specific considerations such as availability of frequencies or need for additional works.
Deferrals are more often the result of external factors rather than any explicit change in priorities between projects.
